editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Acted at the Private Houſe in Blacke Fryers.
LONDON, Printed by Thomas Harper, for Iohn Waterſon, and are to be ſold at his ſhop in Pauls Church-yard, at the ſigne of the Crowne. 1639.

div.head: TO THE NOBLE HONOVRER OF The dead Authors works and memory, Maſter CHARLES COTTON.
div.p:
MY directing of this piece unto you, renders me obvious to many cenſures, which I would willingly prevent by declaring mine owne and your right thereto. Mine was the fortune to be made the unworthy preſerver of it; yours is the worthy opinion you have of the Author and his Poems: neither can it eaſily be determined, whether your affection to them hath made you (by obſerving) more able to judge of them, then your ability to judge of them hath made you to affect
them, deſervedly, not partially. In this preſumptuous act of mine, I expreſſe my twofold zeale; to him and your noble ſelfe, who have built him a more honourable monument in that faire opinion you have of him, then any inſcription ſubject to the wearing of time can be. You will finde him in this Poem as active as in others, to many of which, the dull apprehenſions of former times gave but ſlender allowance, from malitious cuſtome more than reaſon: yet they have ſince by your candid ſelfe and others beene cleerely vindicated. You ſhall oblige by your acceptance of this acknowledgement (which is the beſt I can render you, mine own weake labours being too unworthy your judicious peruſall) him that is ambitious to be known

closer.signed: Your moſt humble ſervant; RICHARD BROME.

div.head: In prayſe of the Authour, and his following Poeme.

lg.l: 'TIs both the life of Action and of wit,
When Actors ſo the fanci'd humours hit,
As if 'twixt them and th' Authour there were ſtrife
How each to other ſhould give mutuall life.
The laſt this wanted not. Invention ſtrayes
Here in full many pleaſant turning wayes,
That like Meanders their curld circles bend,
Yet in a ſmooth ſtreame runne to crowne the end.
Then 'tis authoriz'd by the Authors name;
Who never writ but with ſuch ſprightly flame,
As if the Muſes jointly did inſpire,
His raptures only with their ſacred fire.
And yet perhaps it did participate
At firſt preſenting but of common fate;
When ignorance was judge, and but a few
What was legitimate, what baſtard, knew.
The world's growne wiſer now: each man can ſay
If Fletcher made it 'tis an exc'lent play.
Thus Poemes like their Authors may be ſed,
Never to live 'till they have firſt beene dead.

div.head: Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: HOw dearely welcome you are!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know it,
And my beſt ſiſter, you as deer to my ſight,
And pray let this confirm it, how you have govern'd
My poore ſtate in my abſence, how my ſervants,
I dare and muſt beleeve, elſe I ſhould wrong ye,
The beſt and worthieſt.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: As my womans wit Sir,
Which is but weake and crazie.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: But good Alice
Tell me how fares the gentle Cellide,
The life of my affection, ſince my travell,
My long, and lazie travell? is her love ſtill
Vpon the growing hand? do's it not ſtop
And wither at my yeares? has ſhe not view'd
And entertain'd ſome yonger ſmooth behaviour
Some youth but in his bloſſome, as her ſelfe is?
There lyes my feares.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: They need not, for beleeve me
So well you have manag'd her, and won her minde,
Even from her houres of childehood, to this ripeneſſe,
And in your abſence, that by me inforced ſtil,
So well diſtill'd your gentleneſſe into her,
Obſerv'd her, fed her fancy, liv'd ſtill in her,
And though Love be a boy, and ever youthfull,
And young, and beauteous objects ever aym'd at,
Yet here yee have gone beyond love, better'd nature,
Made him appeare in yeares, in gray yeares fiery,
His bow at full bent ever: feare not brother,
For though your body has been farre off from her,
Yet every houre your heart, which is your goodneſſe,
I have forc'd into her, won a place prepar'd too,
And willingly to give it ever harbour:
Beleeve ſhe is ſo much yours, and won by miracle,
(Which is by age) ſo deep a ſtamp ſet on her
By your obſervances, ſhe cannot alter,
Were the childe living now ye loſt at ſea
Among the Genoway Gallies, what a happineſſe,
What a maine bleſſing?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: O no more good ſiſter,
Touch no more that ſtring, 'tis too harſh and jarring.
With that childe all my hopes went, and you know
The root of all thoſe hopes, the mother too
Within few dayes.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: 'Tis too true, and too fatall,
But peace be with their ſoules.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: For her loſſe
I hope, the beauteous Cellide.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: You may Sir,
For all ſhe is, is yours.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For the poore boyes loſſe,
I have brought a noble friend, I found in travell
A worthier minde, and a more temperate ſpirit
If J have ſo much judgement to diſcerne 'em,
Man yet was never maſter of.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A Gentleman, I doe aſſure my ſelfe,
And of a worthy breeding, though he hide it:
I found him at Valentia, poore and needy,
Onely his minde the maſter of a treaſure.
I ſought his friendſhip, wonne him by much violence,
His honeſty and modeſty ſtill fearing
To thruſt a charge upon me; how I love him,
He ſhall now know, where want and he hereafter
Shall be no more companions: uſe him nobly,
It is my will, good ſiſter, all I have
J make him free companion in, and part er,
But onely

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: I obſerve ye, hold your right there,
Love and high rule allowes no rivals, brother,
He ſhall have faire regard, and all obſervance.

sp.speaker: Hylas
sp.l: Ye are welcome noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What, Monſieur Hylas,
I'me glad to ſee your merry body well yet.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Yf'aith y'are welcome home; what news beyond ſeas?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: None, but new men expected, ſuch as you are
To breed new admirations: 'tis my ſiſter,
Pray ye know her ſir.

sp.speaker: Hylas
sp.l: With all my heart, your leave Lady.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Ye have it ſir.

sp.speaker: Hylas
sp.l: A ſhrewd ſmart touch, which do's prognoſticate
A body keene and active, ſomewhat old,
But that's all one: age brings experience
And knowledge to diſpatch. I muſt be better
And neerer in my ſervice, with your leave ſir,
To this faire Lady.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What, the old ſquire of dames ſtill?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Still the admirer of their goodneſſe with all my heart now
I love a woman of her yeares, a pacer
That lay the bridle in her neck will travell
Forty, and ſomewhat fulſome is a fine diſh,
Theſe yong colts; are too sketiſh.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: My coſin Mary
In all her joy Sir to congratulate
Your faire returne.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My loving, and kind coſin,
A thouſand welcomes.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: A thouſand thanks to heaven Sir
For your ſafe, voyage, and returne.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I thanke • e:
But wher's my bleſſed Cellide? her ſlackneſſe
In viſitation.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Thinke not ſo deere Vncle,
I left her on her knees, thanking the gods
With teares and prayers.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ye have given me too much comfort.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: She will not belong from ye.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Your faire coſin?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is ſo, and a bait you cannot balke ſir,
If your old rule raigne in you, ye may know her.
A happy ſtocke ye have, right worthy Lady,
The pooreſt of your ſervants, vowes his duty
And obliged faith.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: O 'tis a kiſſe you would ſir,
Take it, and tye your tongue up.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I am an aſſe
I doe perceive now: a blinde aſſe, a blockhead:
For this is handſomneſſe, this that that drawes us,
Body and bones: oh what a mounted forehead,
What eyes and lips, what every thing about her?
How like a Swan ſhe ſwims her pace, and beares
Her ſilver breaſts? this is the woman, ſhe,
And onely ſhe, that I will ſo much honour
As to thinke worthy of my love, all older Idols
I heartily abhorre, and give to gunpowder,
And all complexions beſides hers, to Gypſies.

div.stage: Enter Francis at one door, and Cellide at another.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O my deere life, my better heart, all dangers,
Diſtreſſes in my travell, all misfortunes,
Had they been endleſſe like the houres upon me,
In this kiſſe, had been buried in oblivion:
How happy have ye made me, truely happy?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My joy has ſo much overmaſtered me,
That in my teares for your returne.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O deereſt:
My noble friend too: what a bleſſedneſſe
Have I about me now? how full my wiſhes
Are come agen, a thouſand hearty welcomes
I once more lay upon ye: all I have,
The faire and liberall uſe of all my ſervants
To be at your command, and all the uſes
Of al within my power.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ye are too munificent,
Nor am I able to conceive thoſe thanks ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ye wrong my tender love now, even my ſervice,
Nothing accepted, nothing ſtuck between us
And our intire affections, but this woman,
This I beſeech ye friend.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is a jewell
I doe confeſſe would make a thiefe, but never
Of him that's ſo much yours, and bound your ſervant,
That were a baſe ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Ye are noble,
Pray be acquainted with her, keep your way ſir,
My coſin and my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Ye are moſt welcome:

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: If any thing in our poore powers faire ſir
To render ye content, and liberall welcome
May but appeare, command it.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Ye ſhall find us
Happy in our performance.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: The poore ſervant
Of both your goodneſſes preſents his ſervice.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Come no more complement: cuſtome has made it
Dull, old, and tedious: ye are once more welcome,
As your owne thoughts can make ye, and the ſame ever.
And ſo wee'l in to ratifie it.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Harke ye Valentine,
Is wild oates yet come over?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes: with me Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How do's he beare himſelf?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A great deale better:
Why doe you bluſh? the Gentleman will doe well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I ſhould be glad on't Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How do's his Father?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: As mad a worme as ere he was.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: I lookt for't:
Shall we enjoy your companie?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Ile wayt on ye:
Only a thought, or two.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: We bar all prayers. Exeunt all but Hylas.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: This laſt wench, I this laſt wench was a faire one:
A dainty wench, a right one: a devill take it,
What doe I ayle; to have fifteene now in liking
Enough a man would thinke to ſtay my ſtomack,
But what's fifteene, or fifteene ſcore to my thoughts?
And wherefore are mine eyes made, and have lights,
But to encreaſe my objects? this laſt wench
Sticks plaguy cloſe unto me: a hundred pound
I were as cloſe to her: if I lov'd now
As many fooliſh men doe, I ſhould run mad.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: SIrha, no more of your French ſhrugs J adviſe you,
If you be lowzie, ſhift your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: May it pleaſe your worſhip:

sp.speaker: Seb
sp.l: Onely to ſee my ſonne, my ſonne good Launcelot
Your Maſter, and my ſonne: body O me ſir,
No money, no more money Monſieur Launcelot,
Not a deneere, ſweet Signior: bring the perſon,
The perſon of my boy, my boy Tom: Monſieur Thomas,
Or get you gone agen, du gata whee ſir,
Baſſa mi cu, good Launcelot, valetote.
My boy, or nothing.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Then to anſwer punctually.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I ſay to 'th purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Then J ſay to'th purpoſe,
Becauſe your Worſhips vulgar underſtanding
May meet me at the neereſt: your ſonne, my maſter,
Or Monſieur Thomas, (for ſo his travell ſtiles him)
Through many forraigne plots that vertue meets with,
And dangers (I beſeech ye give attention)
Is at the laſt ariv'd
To aske your (as the French man cals it ſweetly)
Benediction, ae jour en jour.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sirha, do not conjure me with your French furies.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Che ditt'a vou, Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Che doga vou, Raſcall:
Leave me your rotten language, and tell me plainely
And quickly ſirha, left I crack your French crowne,
What your good Maſter meanes: I have maintain'd
You and your Monſieur, as I take it Launcelot
Theſe two yeeres at your ditty vous, your jours:
Jour me no more, for not another penny
Shall paſſe my purſe.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Your Worſhip is erroneous,
For as I told you, your Sonne Tom, or Thomas,
My Maſter, and your ſonne is now arriv'd
To aske ye, as our language beares it neereſt
Your quotidian bleſſing, and here he is in perſon.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What Tom, boy, welcome with all my heart boy,
Welcome 'faith, thou haſt gladded me at ſoule boy,
Infinite glad I am, I have praied too, Thomas
For you wilde Thomas, Tom, I thank thee hartily
For comming home.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, I doe finde your prayers
Have much much prevail'd above my ſins.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Elſe certaine I had periſh'd with my rudeneſſe,
Ere J had won my ſelfe to that diſcretion
I hope you ſhall hereafter finde.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Humh, humh,
Diſcretion? is it come to that? the boy's ſpoild.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sirah, you rogue, look for't, for I will make thee
Ten times more miſerable then thou thoughtſt thy ſelfe
Before thou travelledſt: thou haſt told my father
I know it, and I finde it, all my rogueries
By meere way of prevention to undoe me.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Sir, as J ſpeake eight languages, I onely
Told him you came to aske his benediction,

l.hi: De jour enjour.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: But that I muſt be civill,
I would beat thee like a dog: ſir, howſoever
The time I have miſpent may make you doubtfull,
Nay, harden your beliefe 'gainſt my converſion,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A pox o' travell, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Yet deere father
Your owne experience in my after courſes.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Prethee no more; t'is ſcurvy; ther's thy ſiſter
Vndon without redemption: he eates with picks
Vtterly ſpoyld, his ſpirit baffell'd in him.
How have I find that this affliction
Should light ſo heavie on me. I have no more ſonnes;
And this no more mine owne, no ſpark of nature
Allows him mine now, he's growne tame: my grand curſe
Hang ore his head that thus transform'd thee: travell?
Ile ſend my horſe to travell next: we monſieur,
Now will my moſt canonicall deere neighbours
Say I have found my ſonne, and rejoyce with me
Becauſe he has mew'd his mad tricks off. I know not,
But I am ſure; this Monſieur, this fine gentleman
Will never be in my books like mad Thomas,
I muſt goe ſeeke an heire, for my inheritance
Muſt not turne ſecretary: my name and quality
Has kept my land three hundred yeers in madneſſe,
And it ſlip now, may it ſinke. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Excellent ſiſter,
I am glad to ſee thee well: but wher's my father?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Gone diſcontent, it ſeemes.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: He did ill in it
As he dos all: for I was uttering
A handſome ſpeech or two, I have been ſtudying
Ere ſince I came from Paris: how glad to ſee thee?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I am gladder to ſee you, with more love too
I dare maintaine it, then my fathers ſorry
To ſee (as he ſuppoſes) your converſion:
And I am ſure he is vext, nay more I know it,
He has prai'd againſt it mainely: but it appeares ſir
Ye had rather blinde him with that poore opinion,
Then in your ſelfe correct it, deereſt brother,
Since there is in our uniforme reſemblance,
No more to make us two, but our bare ſexes:
And ſince one happy birth produced us hither,
Let one more happy minde.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ir ſhallbe ſiſter,
For I can doe it when I liſt: a • d yet wench
Be mad too when I pleaſe: I have the trick on't.
Beware a traveller.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Leave that trick too,

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Not for the world: but wher's my Miſtreſſe
And prethee ſay how do's ſhe? I melt to ſee her,
And preſently: I muſt a way.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then doe ſo.
For o' my fath ſhe will not ſee your brother.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Not ſee me? I'le.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Now you play your true ſelf;
How would my father love this! I'le aſſure ye
She will not ſee you: ſhe has heard, (and lowdly)
The gambolls that you plaid ſince your departure,
In every Towne ye came, your ſeverall miſcheifes.
Your rowſes, and your wenches: all your quarrells,
And the no cauſes of 'em: theſe I take it
Although ſhe love ye well, to modeſt eares,
To one that waited for your reformation,
To which end travell was propounded by her Vncle,
Muſt needs, and reaſon for it, be examined,
And by her modeſty, and fear'd too light too
To fyle with her affections: ye have loſt her
For any thing I ſee, exil'd your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: No more of that ſweet Doll, I will be civill.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: But how long?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Wouldſt thou have me loſe my birth-right?
For yond old thing will diſinherit me
If I grow too demure: good ſweet Doll, prethee:
Prethee deere ſiſter, let me ſee her.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Nay, I beſeech thee: by this light.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I: ſwagger.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Kiſſe me, and be my friend, we two were twins.
And ſhall we now grow ſtrangers?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Tis not my fault,

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Well, there be other women, and remember
You, you were the cauſe of this: there be more lands too,
And better people in 'em: fare ye well,
And other loves: what ſhall become of me
And of my vanities, becauſe they grieve ye.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Come hither, come, do you ſee that clowd that flyes there?
So light are you, and blown with every fancy:
Will ye but make me hope ye may be civill?
I know your nature's ſweet enough, and tender,
Not grated on, nor curb'd: doe you love your Miſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: He lyes, that ſayes I doe not.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Would ye ſee her?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: If you pleaſe: for it muſt be ſo.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And appeare to her
A thing to be belov'd?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Change then
A little of your wildeneſſe into wiſedome,
And put on a more ſmoothneſſe:
I'le doe the beſt I can to helpe ye, yet
I doe proteſt ſhe ſwore, and ſwore it deeply,
She would never ſee you more: where's your mans heart now?
What doe you faint at this?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: She is a woman:
But he ſhe entertaines next for a ſervant,
I ſhall be bold to quarter.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No thought of fighting:
Goe in, and there wee'l talke more: be but rul'd,
And what lyes in my power, ye ſhall be ſure of.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: HEe cannot be ſo wilde ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt certaine
I have now heard all, and all the truth.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Grant all that:
Is he the firſt, that h'as bin giv'n a loſt man,
And yet come fairely home? he is yong, and tender
And fit for that impreſſion; your affections
Shall ſtamp upon him, age brings on diſcretion,
A yeere hence, theſe mad toyes that now poſſeſſe him
Will ſhew like bugbeares to him, ſhapes to fright him;
Marriage diſſolves all theſe like miſts.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They are grounded
Hereditary in him, from his father
And to his grave they will haunt him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Tis your feare
Which is a wiſe part in you; yet your love
However you may ſeeme to leſſen it
with theſe diſlikes, and choake it with theſe errors,
Do what you can will break out to excuſe him,
Ye have him in your hart, and planted, Coſin,
From whence the power of reaſon, nor diſcretion
Can ever roote him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Planted in my heart Aunt?
Beleeve it no, I never was ſo liberall:
What though he ſhew a ſo ſo comely fellow
Which we call pretty? or ſay it may be hanſom?
What though his promiſes may ſtumble at
The power of goodneſſe in him, ſometimes uſe too?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How willingly thy heart betrayes thee coſin?
Cozen thy ſelfe no more: thou haſt no more power
To leave off loving him, then he that's thirſty
Has to abſtaine from drinke ſtanding before him.
His mind is not ſo monſtrous for his ſhape
If I have eyes; I have not ſeene his better.
A hanſom browne complexion

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Reaſonable
Inclining to a tawney.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Had I ſaid ſo
You would have wiſh'd my tongue out: then his making.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Which may be mended: I have ſeene leggs ſtraiter.
And cleaner made.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A body too,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Far neater,
And better ſet together.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: God forgive thee,
For againſt thy conſcience thou lyeſt ſtubbornely.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I grant 'tis neat enough.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: 'Tis excellent,
And where the outward parts are faire and lovely,
(Which are but molds o'th minde) what muſt the ſoule be?
Put caſe youth has his ſwinge, and fyery nature
Flames to mad uſes many times.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: All this
You onely uſe, to make me ſay I love him:
I doe confeſſe I doe, but that my fondneſſe
Should fling it ſelfe upon his deſperate follies.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: I doe not counſell that, ſee him reclaim'd firſt,
Which will not prove a miracle, yet Mary
I am afraid 'twill vexe thee horribly
To ſtay ſo long.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, no Aunt, no beleeve me.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: What was your dreame to night? for I obſerv'd ye
Hugging of me; with good, deere, ſweet Tom.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fye Aunt,
Vpon my conſcience.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: On my word 'tis true wench:
And then ye kiſs'd me Mary, more then once too,
And ſigh'd, and O ſweet Tom againe: nay, doe not bluſh,
Ye have it at the heart wench.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'le be hang'd firſt,
But you muſt have your way. Enter Dorothea.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: And ſo will you too,
Or breake down hedges for it: Dorothea,
The welcom'ſt woman living: how do's thy brother?
I heare he's turn'd a wondrous civill gentleman
Since his ſhort travell.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pray heaven he make it good Alice.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How doe ye friend, I have a quarrell to ye,
Ye ſtole away, and left my company.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O pardon me, deere friend, it was to welcome
A brother, that I have ſome cauſe to love well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Prethee how is he? thou ſpeakſt truth.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Not perfect:
I hope he will be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Never: ha's forgot me,
I heare wench, and his hot love too:

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Thou wouldſt howle then.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I am glad it ſhould be ſo; his travels
Have yeelded him variety of Miſtreſſes,
Fairer in his eye farre.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: O cogging raſcall.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I was a foole, but better thoughts I thank heaven.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pray do not think ſo, for he loves you deerely,
Vpon my troth moſt firmely: would faine ſee you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: See me friend? doe you thinke it fit?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It may be,
Without the loſſe of credit too: he's not
Such a prodigious thing, ſo monſtrous,
To fling from all ſociety.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: His ſo much contrary
To my deſires, ſuch an antipathy
That I muſt ſooner ſee my grave.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Deere friend,
He was not ſo before he went.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I grant it,
For then I daily hop'd his faire converſion.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Come, do not maske your ſelfe, but ſee him freely,
Ye have a minde.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That minde I'le maſter then.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And is your hate ſo mortall?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not to his perſon,
But to his qualities, his mad-cap follies,
Which ſtill like Hydras heads grow thicker on him.
I have a credit friend, and maids of my ſort,
Love where their modeſties may live untainted.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I give up that hope then: pray, for your friends ſake,
If I have any intereſt within ye,
Doe but this courteſie, accept this Letter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: From him?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The ſame: 'tis but a minutes reading,
And as we looke on ſhapes of painted divels,
Which for the preſent may diſturb our fancy,
But with the next new object looſe 'em, ſo
If this be foule, ye may forget it, 'pray:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have ye ſeene it friend?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will not lye: I have not,
But I preſume, ſo much he honours you,
The worſt part of himſelfe was caſt away
When to his beſt part he writ this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For your ſake,
Not that I any way ſhall like his ſcribling.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: A ſhrewd diſſembling queane.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: J thanke ye deere friend,
I know ſhe loves him.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Yes, and will not looſe him,
Vnleſſe he leap into the Moone, beleeve that,
And then ſhee'l ſcramble too: yong wenches loves
Are like the courſe of quarterns, they may ſhift
And ſeeme to ceaſe ſometimes, and yet we ſee
The leaſt diſtemper puls 'em backe againe,
And ſeats 'em in their old courſe: feare her not,
Vnleſſe he be a devill.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now heaven bleſſe me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What has he writ?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Out, out upon him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Ha, what has the mad man done?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Worſe, worſe, and worſe ſtill,

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Some northerne toy, a little broad.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Still fowler?
Hay, hay boyes: goodneſſe keep me: oh:

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What ayle ye?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here, take your ſpell againe, it burnes my fingers.
Was ever Lover writ ſo ſweet a Letter,
So elegant a ſtile? pray looke upon't:
The rareſt inventory of ranke oathes
That ever cut-purſe caſt.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: What a mad boy is this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Onely i'th bottome
A little julip gently ſprinckled over
To coole his mouth, leſt it breake out in bliſters,
Indeed law. Yours for ever.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I am ſorry.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You ſhall be welcome to me, eome when you pleaſe,
And ever may command me vertuouſly,
But for your brother, you muſt pardon me,
Till I am of his nature, no acceſſe friend,
No word of viſitation, as ye love me,
And ſo for now Ile leave ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: What a letter
Has this thing written, how it roares like thunder?
With what a ſtate he enters into ſtile.
Deere Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Out upon him bedlam.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Well, there be waies to reach her yet: ſuch likeneſſe
As you two carry me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I am mad too,
And yet can apprehend ye: fare ye well,
The foole ſhall now fiſh for himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Be ſure then
His tewgh be tith and ſtrong: and next no ſwearing,
He'l catch no fiſh elſe. Farewell Doll.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Farewell Alice. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: INdeed he's much chang'd, extreamely alter'd,
His colour faded ſtrangely too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The ayre,
The ſharpe and nipping ayre of our new clymat
I hope is all, which will as well reſtore
To health againe th'affected body by it,
And make it ſtronger far, as leave it dangerous;
How do's my ſweet, our bleſſed houre comes on now
Apace my Cellide, (it knocks at dore)
In which our loves, and long deſires like rivers
Riſing aſunder far, ſhall fall together,
Within theſe too daies deere.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: When heaven, and you ſir
Shall thinke it fit: for by your wils I am govern'd,

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: 'Twere good ſome preparation.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: All that may be:
It ſhall be no blinde wedding: and all the joy
Of all our friends I hope: he lookes worſe hourely:
How do's my friend, my ſelfe? he ſweats too coldly,
His pulſe, like the ſlow dropping of a ſpowt,
Scarce gives his function: how i'st man, alas ſir,
You looke extreme ill: is it any old griefe,
The weight of which?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: None, gentle ſir, that I feele
Your love is too too tender.
Nay beleeve ſir,

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: You cannot be the maſter of your health,
Either ſome feaver lyes in wait to catch ye,
Whoſe harbinger's already in your face
We ſee preparing: or ſome diſcontent,
Which if it lye in this houſe, I dare ſay
Both for this noble Gentleman, and all
That live within it, ſhall as readily
Be purg'd away, and with as much care ſoften'd,
And where the cauſe is.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis a joy to be ill,
Where ſuch a vertuous faire Phyſitian
Is ready to releeve: your noble cares
I muſt, and ever ſhall be thankfull for,
And would my ſervice (I dare not looke upon her)
But be not fearefull, I feele nothing dangerous,
A grudging caus'd by th' alteration
Of ayre, may hang upon me: my heart's whole,
(I would it were)

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: I knew the cauſe to be ſo.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: No, you ſhall never know it.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Some warme broths
To purge the bloud, and keep your bed a day Sir,
And ſweat it out.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have ſuch cordials,
That if you will but promiſe me to take 'em,
Indeed you ſhall be well, and very quickly,
I'le be your Doctor, you ſhall ſee how finely
I'le fetch ye up againe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He ſweats extreamely:
Hot, very hot: his pulſe beats like a drum now,
Feele ſiſter, feele, feele ſweet.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How that touch ſtung me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My gowne there.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And thoſe julips in the window.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Some ſee his bed made.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is moſt unhappy,
Take courage man, 'tis nothing but an ague.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: And this ſhall be the laſt fit.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Not by thouſands:
Now what 'tis to be truely miſerable,
I feele at full experience.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: He growes fainter.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Come, leade him in, he ſhall to bed: a vomit,
I'le have a vomit for him.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: A purge firſt,
And if he breath'd a veyne.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: No, no, no bleeding,
A Clyſter will coole all.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Be of good cheere Sir.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: He's loth to ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How hard he holds my hand Aunt?

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: I doe not like that ſigne.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Away to's chamber,
Softly, he's full of paine, be diligent
With all the care ye have: would I had ſcus'd him. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: VVHy do you raile at me? do I dwell in her
To force her to do this or that? your Letter,
A wilde-fire on your Letter; our ſweet Letter;
You are ſo learned in your writs: ye ſtand now
As if ye had worried ſheepe: you muſt tutne tippet,
And ſuddenly, and truely, and diſcreetly
Put on the ſhape of order and humanity,
Or you muſt marry Malkyn the May Lady:
You muſt, deere brother: doe you make me carrier
Of your confound-mee's, and your culverings?
Am I a ſeemely agent for your othes?
Who would have writ ſuch a deboſh'd?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Your patience,
May not a man profeſſe his Love?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: In blaſphemies?
Rack a maids tender cares, with dam's and divels?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Out, out upon thee.
how would you have me write?
Begin with my love premiſed? ſurely,
And by my truly Miſtreſſe

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Take your owne courſe
For I ſee all perſwaſion's loſt upon ye:
Humanitie, all drownd: from this howre fayrely

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Ile waſh my hands of all ye do: farewell Sir.
Thou art not mad?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No, if I were, deere brother
I would keep you company: get a new Miſtreſſe
Som ſuburb Sant, that ſix pence, and ſom others
Will draw to parley: carowſe her health in Cans
And candles ends, and quarrell for her beauty,
Such a ſweet hart muſt ſerve your turne: your old love
Releaſes ye of all your tyes; diſclaimes ye
And utterly abjures your memory
Till time has better mannag'd ye, will ye comand me

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What bobd of all ſides?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Any worthy ſervice
Vnto my father ſir, that I may tell him
Even to his peace of heart, and much rejoycing
Ye are his true ſon Thom ſtill? will it pleaſe ye
To beat ſome halfe a dozen of his ſervants preſently
That I may teſtifie you have brought the ſame faith
Vnblemiſhd home, ye carried out? or if it like you
There be two chambermaids within, yong wenches,
Handſom and apt for exerciſe: you have bin good, ſir,
And charitable though I ſay it Signiour
To ſuch poore orphans: and now, by th' way I think on't
Your yong reare Admirall, I meane your laſt baſtard
Don Iohn, ye had by Lady Blanch the Dairy Maid,
Is by an Academy of learned Gypſies,
Foreſeeing ſome ſtrange wonder in the infant
Stolne from the Nurſe, and wanders with thoſe Prophets.
There is plate in the parlour, and good ſtore ſir,
When your wants ſhall ſupply it. So moſt humbly
(Firſt rendring my due ſervice) I take leave ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why Doll, why Doll I ſay: my letter ſubd too,
And no acceſſe without I mend my manners?
All my deſignes in Limbo? I will have her,
Yes, I will have her, though the divell rore,
I am reſolv'd that, if ſhe live above ground,
I'le not be bobd i'th noſe with every bobtaile:
I will be civill too: now I thinke better,
Exceeding civill, wondrous finely carried:
And yet be mad upon occaſion,
And ſtarke mad too, and ſave my land: my father:
I'le have my will of him, how ere my wench goes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sirha, I ſay ſtill you have ſpoild your Maſter: leave your ſtiches:
I ſay thou haſt ſpoild thy maſter.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I ſay how ſir?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Marry thou haſt taught him like an arrant raſcall,
Firſt to reade perfectly: which on my bleſſing
I warn'd him from: for I knew if he read once,
He was a loſt man. Secondly, ſir Launcelot,
Sir lowſie Launcelot, ye have ſuffer'd him
Againſt my power firſt, then againſt my precept,
To keepe that ſimpring ſort of people company,
That ſober men call civill: marke ye that Sir?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And't pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It does not pleaſe my worſhip,
Nor ſhall not pleaſe my worſhip: third and laſtly,
Which if the law were here, I would hang thee for,
(However I will lame thee) like a villaine,
Thou haſt wrought him
Cleane to forget what 'tis to doe a miſchiefe,
A handſome miſchiefe, ſuch as thou knew'ſt I lov'd well.
My ſervants all are ſound now, my drink ſowrd,
Not a horſe pawnd, nor plaid away: no warrants
Come for the breach of peace.
Men travell with their money, and nothing meets 'em:
I was accurs'd to ſend thee, thou wert ever
Leaning to lazineſſe, and loſſe of ſpirit,
Thou ſlept'ſt ſtill like a corke upon the water,
Your worſhip knowes, I ever was accounted
The moſt deboſh'd, and pleaſe you to remember,
Every day drunke too, for your worſhips credit,
I broke the Butlers head too.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No baſe Palliard
J doe remember yet that anſlaight, thou waſt beaten,
And fledſt before the Butler: a blacke jacke
Playing vpon thee furiouſly, J ſaw it:
I ſaw thee ſcatter'd rogue, behold thy Maſter.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: What ſweet content dwels here?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Put up your booke ſir,
We are all undone elſe.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Tom, when is the horſe-race?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I know not ſir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You will be there?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Not I ſir,
I have forgot thoſe journeyes.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Spoild for ever,
The cocking holds at Derby, and there will be
Iacke Wild-oats, and Will Purſer.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I am ſorry ſir,
They ſhould employ their time ſo ſlenderly,
Their underſtandings will beare better courſes.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Yes, I will marry agen: but Monſieur Thomas,
What ſay ye to the gentleman that challenged ye
Before he went, and the fellow ye fell out with?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: O good Sir,
Remember not thoſe follies: where I have wronged ſir,
(So much I have now learn'd to diſcern my ſelfe)
My meanes, and my repentance ſhall make even,
Nor doe I thinke it any imputation
To let the law p • rſwade me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Any woman:
I care not of what colour, or complexion,
Any that can beare children: reſt ye merry. Exit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ye have utterly undone: cleane diſcharg'd me,
I am for the ragged regiment.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Eight languages,
And wither at an old mans words?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O pardon me.
I know him but too well: eight ſcore I take it
Will not keepe me from beating, if not killing:
I'le give him leave to breake a leg, and thank him:
You might have ſav'd all this, and ſworn a little.
What had an oath or two bin? or a head broke,
Though t'had been mine, to have ſatisſied the old man?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I'le breake it yet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Now 'tis too late, I take it:
Will ye be drunk to night, (a leſſe intreaty
Has ſerv'd your turne) and ſave all yet? not mad drunk,
For then ye are the divell, yet the drunker,
The better for your father ſtill: your ſtate is deſperate,
And with a deſperate cure ye muſt recover it:
Doe ſomething, doe ſir: doe ſome drunken thing,
Some mad thing, or ſome any thing to help us.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Goe for a Fidler then: the poore old Fidler
That ſayes his ſongs: but firſt where lyes my Miſtreſſe,
Did ye enquire out that?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'th Lodge, alone ſir,
None but her owne attendants.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: 'Tis the happier:
Away then, finde this Fidler, and doe not miſſe me
By nine a clocke.

l.hi: Via.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: My father's mad now,
And ten to one will diſinherite me:
I'le put him to his plunge, and yet be merry,
What Rybabalde?

l.hi: Don Thomaſio.
De bene venew.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I doe embrace your body:
How do'ſt thou Sam.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: The ſame Sam ſtill: your friend ſir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And how is't bouncing boyes?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Thou art not alter'd,
They ſaid thou wert all Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O beleeve it,
I am much alter'd, much another way:
The civil'ſt Gentleman in all your Country:
Doe not ye ſee me alter'd? ye, and nay Gentlemen,
A much converted man: wher's the beſt wine boyes?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: A ſound Convertite.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What haſt thou made up twenty yet?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: By'r Lady,
I have giv'n a ſhrewd puſh at it, for as I take it,
The laſt I fell in love with, ſcor'd ſixteene.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Look to your skin, Rambaldo the ſleeping Gyant
Will rowze, and rent thee piece-meale.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: He nev'r perceives 'em
Longer then looking on.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou never meaneſt then
To marry any that thou lov'ſt?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: No ſurely,
Nor any wiſe man I thinke; marriage?
Would you have me now begin to be prentize,
And learne to cobble other mens old boots?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Why you may take a Maid.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Where? can you tell me?
Or if 'twere poſſible I might get a Maid,
To what uſe ſhould I put her? looke upon her,
Dandle her upon my knee, and give her ſuger ſops?
All the new gowns i'th pariſh will not pleaſe her,
If ſhe be high bred, for ther's the ſport ſhe aymes at,
Nor all the feathers in the Fryars.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Then take a widow,
A good ſtanch wench, that tith,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: And begin a new order,
Live in a dead mans monument, not I ſir,
I'le keep mine old road, a true mendicant:
What pleaſure this day yeelds me, I never covet
To lay up for the morrow: and me thinks ever
Another mans cooke dreſſes my dyet neateſt.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Thou waſt wont to love old women, fat, and flat noſed,
And thou wouldſt ſay they kiſt like Flounders, flat
All the face over.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: J have had ſuch damſels
J muſt confeſſe.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou haſt been a pretious rogue.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Onely his eyes: and O my conſcience
They lye with half the kingdome.

div.stage: Enter over the ſtage, Phyſitians and others.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What's the matter?
Whither goe all theſe men-menders, theſe Phyſitians?
Whoſe dog lyes ſicke o'th mulligrubs?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O the Gentleman,
The yong ſmug Signiour, Maſter Ʋalentine,
Brought out of travell with him, as J heare
Is falne ſick o'th ſudden, deſperate ſicke,
And likely they goe thither.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Who? yong Frank?
The onely temper'd ſpirit, Scholler, Souldier,
Courtier: and all in one piece? 'tis not poſſible.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Ther's one can better ſatisfie you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Miſtreſſe Alice,
I joy to ſee you Lady.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Good Monſieur Thomas,
You'r welcome from your travell: I am haſty,
A Gentleman lies ſicke ſir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And how do'ſt thou?
I muſt know, and I will know.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Excellent well,
As well as may be, thank ye.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I am glad on't,
And prethee harke.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: I cannot ſtay.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: A while Alice.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Never looke ſo narrowly, the mark's in her mouth ſtill,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I am looking at her legs, prethee be quiet.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: I cannot ſtay.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: O ſweete Alice.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: A cleane inſtep,
And that I love a life: I did not marke
This woman halfe ſo well before, how quicke
And nimble like a ſhadow, there her leg ſhew'd:
By th' mas a neat one, the colour of her ſtocking,
A much inviting colour.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: My good Monſieur,
I have no time to talke now,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Pretty breeches,
Finely becomming too.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: By heaven.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: She will not,
I can aſſure you that, and ſo

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: But this word.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: I cannot, nor I will not: good Lord. Ezit.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Well you ſhall heare more from me.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Wee'll goe viſite
'Tis charity: beſides I know ſhe is there:
And under viſitation I ſhall ſee hir
Will ye along?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: By any meanes.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Be ſure then
I be a civill man: J have ſport in hand boyes
Shall make mirth for a marriage day.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Away then. Exeunt

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter three Phyſitians with an Vrinall.

sp.speaker: 1 Phiſ.
sp.l: A Pluriſie. I ſee it.
I rather hold it
For tremor cordis.
Doe you marke the Pheſes?
'Tis a moſt peſtilent contagious feaver,
A ſurfet, a plaguy ſurfet: he muſt bleed.
By no meanes.
I ſay bleed.
I ſay 'tis dangerous:
The perſon being ſpent ſo much before hand,
And nature drawne ſo low, clyſters, coole clyſters.
Now with your favours, J ſhould think a vomit:
For take away the cauſe, the effect muſt follow,
The ſtomack's foule and fur'd, the pot's unflam'd yet.
No, no, wee'l rectifie that part by milde meanes,
Nature ſo ſunke, muſt finde no violence.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Wilt pleaſe ye draw neere? the weake gentleman
Growes worſe and worſe ſtill.
Come, we will attend him.
He ſhall doe well my friend.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My maſters love ſir.
Excellent well I warrant thee, right and ſtraight friend.
Ther's no doubt in him, none at all, nev'r feare him.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: THat he is deſp • rate ſick, I do beleeve well,
And that without a ſp • edy cure, it kils him,
But that it lyes within the help • of phyſicke,
Now to reſtore his health, or art to cure him:
Beleeve it you are coſened: cleane beſide it.
I would tell ye the true cauſe too, but 'twould vexe ye,
Nay, run ye mad.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: May all I have reſtore him?
So deerely and ſo tenderly I love him,
I doe not know the cauſe why, yea my life too.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Now I perceive ye ſo well ſet, I'le tell you,

l.hi: Hei mihi quod nullis amor, eſt medicabilis herbis.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Twas that I onely fear'd: good friend go from me,
I finde my heart too full for further conference:
You are aſſur'd of this?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: 'Twill prove too certaine,
But beare it nobly ſir, youth hath his errors.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I ſhall do, and I thank ye: pray ye no words on't,
I doe not uſe to talke ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Ye are welcome:
Is there no conſtancy in earthly things:
No happineſſe in us, but what muſt alter,
No life without the heavy load of fortune?
What miſeries we are, and to our ſelves,
Even then when full content ſeemes to ſit by us,
What daily ſores, and ſorrowes?

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: O deere brother,
The Gentleman if ev • r you will ſee him
Alive as I think.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O he faints, for heaven ſake,
For heaven ſake ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Goe comfort him deere ſiſter. Exit Alice.
And one word ſweet, with you: then we'l go to him.
What think you of this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My pity thinks ſir,
'Tis great misfortune, that he ſhould thus periſh.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is indeed: but Cellide, he muſt dye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That were a cruelty, when care may cure him,
Why doe you weep ſo ſir, he may recover?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He may, but with much danger: my ſweet Cellide
You have a powerfull tongue.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To doe you ſervice.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: J will betray his griefe: he loves a gentlewoman,
A friend of yours, whoſe heart another holds,
He knowes it too: yet ſuch a ſway blinde fancy,
And his not daring to deliver it,
Have won upon him, that they muſt undoe him:
Never ſo hopefull and ſo ſweet a ſpirit,
Misfortune fell ſo foule on.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sure ſhe's hard hearted,
That can looke on, and not relent, and deeply
At ſuch a miſery: ſhe is not married?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nor neere it?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: When ſhe pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And pray ſir,
Do's he deſerve her truely, that ſhe loves ſo?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: His love may merit much: his perſon little,
For there the match lyes mangled.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Is he your friend?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: He ſhould be, for he is neere me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Will not he dye then?
When th'other ſhall recover?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ye have pos'd me.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Me thinks he ſhould goe neere it, if he love her;
If ſhe love him

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She do's, and would doe equall:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis A hard taske you put me: yet for your ſake
I will ſpeake to her: all the art I have:
My beſt endevors: all his youth, and perſon,
His mind more full of beautis: all his hopes,
The memory of ſuch a ſad example,
Ill ſpoken of, and never old: the curſes
Of loving maids, and what may be alleag'd
Ile lay before her: what's her name? I am ready

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But will you deale effectually?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Moſt truly:
Nay were it my ſelfe, at your entreaty.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.l: And could ye be ſo pittifull?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: So dutifull;
Becauſe you urge it ſir,

sp.speaker: Ʋall.
sp.l: It may be then
It is your ſelfe

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: It is in deed, I know it.
And now know how ye love me.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.l: O my deareſt,
Let but your goodneſſe judge: your owne part: pitiy:
Set but your eyes on his afflictions:
He is mine, and ſo becomes your charge: but thinke
What ruine nature ſuffers in this yong man,
What loſſe humanity, and noble manhood:
Take to your better judgement my declining,
My age, hung full of impotence, and ils,
My body budding now no more: ſeere winter
Hath ſeal'd that ſap up, at the beſt and happieſt
I can but be your infant: you my nurſe,
And how unequall deereſt: where his yeeres,
His ſweetneſſe, and his ever ſpring of goodneſſe,
My fortunes growing in him, and my ſelfe too,
Which makes him all your old love: miſconceive not,
I ſay not this, as weary of my bondage,
Or ready to infringe my faith: beare witneſſe,
Thoſe eyes that I adore ſtill, thoſe lamps that light me
To all the joy I have.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You have ſaid enough ſir,
And more then ere I thought that tongue could utter,
But ye are a man, a falſe man too.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Deere Cellide.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And now, to ſhew you that I am a woman
Rob'd of her reſt, and fool'd out of her fondneſſe,
The Gentleman ſhall live: and if he love me,
Ye ſhall be both my triumphs: I will to him,
And as you careleſly fling off your fortune,
And now grow weary of my eaſie winning,
So will I loſe the name of Valentine,
From henceforth all his flatteries, and beleeve it,
Since ye have ſo ſo ſlightly parted with affection,
And that affection you have pawn'd your faith for:
From this houre, no repentance, vowes, nor prayers
Shall plucke me backe agen: what I ſhall doe,
Yet I will undertake his cure, expect it,
Shall miniſter no comfort, no content
To either of ye, but hourely more vexations.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Why let him dye then.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, ſo much I have loved
To be commanded by you, that even now,
Even in my hate I will obey your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What ſhall I doe?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Dye like a foole unſorrow'd?
A bankrupt foole, that flings away his treaſure?
I muſt begin my cure.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: And I my croſſes. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Franckſick, Phyſitians, and a Pothecary.

sp.speaker: 1 Phiſ.
sp.l: CLap on the Cataplaſme.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Good Gentlemen,
Good learned Gentlemen.
And ſee thoſe brothe • there,
Ready within this houre, pray keep your armes in,
The ayre is raw, and miniſters much evill.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pray leave me: I beſeech ye leave me gentlemen.
I have no other ſickneſſe but your preſence,
Convey your Cataplaſmes to thoſe that need 'em,
Your Vomits, and your Clyſters.
Pray be rul'd ſir.
Bring in the Lettice cap: you muſt be ſhaved ſir,
And then how ſuddenly wee'l make you ſleep.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Till doomeſ-day: what unneceſſary nothings
Are theſe about a wounded minde?
How doe ye?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What queſtions they propound too: how do you ſir?
I am glad to ſee you well.
A great diſtemper, it growes hotter ſtill.
Open your mouth I pray ſir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And can you tell me
How old I am then? there's my hand, pray ſhew me
How many broken ſhins within this two yeare.
Who would be thus in fetters, good maſter Doctor,
And you deere Doctor, and the third ſweet Doctor
And pretious maſter Apothecary, I doe pray ye
To give me leave to live a little longer,
Ye ſtand before me like my blacks.
'Tis dangerous,
For now his fancy turnes too.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: By your leave Gentlemen:
And pray ye your leave a while too, I have ſomething
Of ſecret to imparr unto the patient.
Withall our hearts.
I mary ſuch a Phyſicke
May chance to find the humour: be not long Lady
For we muſt miniſter within this halfe houre. Exit. Plus.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: You ſhall not ſtay for me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Would you were all rotten
That ye might only intend one anothers itches:
Or would the Gentlemen with one conſent
Would drinke ſmall Beere but ſeven yeare, and aboliſh
That wildfire of the bloud, unſatiate wenching
That your too Indies, ſprings and fals might faile ye
What torments theſe intruders into bodies.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: How do you worthy Sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Bleſſe me, what beames
Flew from theſe angell eyes: O what a miſery
What a moſt ſtuddied torment tis to me now
To be an honeſt man: dare ye ſit by me?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Yes; and do more then that too: comfort ye
I ſee ye have need.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You are a faire Phyſitian:
You bring no bitterneſſe gilt ore, to gull us
No danger in your lookes, yet there my death lyes.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: I would be ſorry ſir, my charity
And my good wiſhes for your health ſhould merit
So ſtubborn • a conſtruction: will it pleaſe ye
To taſte a little of this Cordiall Enter Valentine.
For this I thinke muſt cure ye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Of which Lady?
Sure ſhe has found my griefe? why do you bluſh ſo?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Do you not underſtand? of this, this Cordiall.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Of my afflicted heart: ſhe is gon for ever.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What heaven ye have brought me Lady?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Do not wonder:
For tis not impudence, nor want of honour
Makes me do this: but love to ſave your life ſir
Your life, too excellent to looſe in wiſhes
Love, virtuous love.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A vertuous bleſſing crowne ye
O goodly ſweet, can there be ſo much charity
So noble a compaſſion in that heart
That's filled up with anothers faire affections?
Can mercy drop from thoſe eyes.
Can miracles be wrought upon a dead man,
When all the power ye have, and perfect object
Lyes in anothers light: and his deſerves it?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Do not diſpaire: nor do not thinke to boldly
I dare abuſe my promiſe, t'was your friends
And ſo faſt tyde, I thought no time could ruine:
But ſo much has your danger, and that ſpell
The powerfull name of friend, prevail'd above him
To whom I ever owe obedience,
That here I am, by his command to cure ye,
Nay more for ever, by his full reſignement
And willingly I ratefie it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Hold for heaven ſake,
Muſt my friends miſery make me a triumph?
Beare I that noble name, to be a Traitor?
O vertuous goodnes, keepe thy ſelfe untainted:
You have no power to yeeld, nor he to render
Nor I to take: I am reſolv'd to die firſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha; ſaiſt thou ſo? nay then thou ſhalt not periſh.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And though I love ye above the light ſhines on me,
Beyond the wealth of Kingdomes, free content,
Sooner would ſnatch at ſuch a bleſſing offer'd
Then at my pardon'd life by the law forfeited,
Yet, yet O noble beauty, yet O paradiſe
For you are all the wonder reveal'd of it,
Yet is a gratitude to be preſerv'd
A worthy gratitude to one moſt worthy.
The name, and noblenes of friends.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Pray tell me
If I had never knowne that gentleman
Would you not willingly embrace my offer?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do you make a doubt?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: And can ye be unwilling
He being old and impotent: his aime too
Levell'd at you, for your good? not conſtrain'd,
But out of cure, and councell? alas conſider
Play but the woman with me, and conſider
As he himſelfe do's, and I now dare ſee it
Truly conſider ſir, what miſery.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: For vertues ſake take heed.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: What loſſe of youth,
What everlaſting baniſhment from that
Our yeares doe only covet to arive at
Equall affections and ſhot together:
What living name can dead age leave behind him
What art of memory but fruitleſſe doating?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This cannot be.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: To you unleſſe ye apply it
With more and firmer faith, and ſo digeſt it
I ſpeake but of things poſſible, not done
Nor like to be, a poſſet cures your ſickneſſe
And yet I know ye grieve this; and howſoever
The worthines of Friend may make ye ſtagger
Which is a faire thing in ye, yet my Patient,
My gentle Patient, I would faine ſay more
If you would underſtand.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O cruell Woman.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Yet ſure your ſickneſſe is not ſo forgetfull
Nor you ſo willing to be loſt.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pray ſtay there:
Me thinks you are not faire now; me thinks more
That modeſt, vertue, men delivered of you
Shewes but like ſhadow to me, thin, and fading.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Excellent Friend.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Ye have no ſhare in goodneſſe:
Ye are belyde; you are not Cellide,
The modeſt, unaculate: who are ye?
For I will know: what devill to do miſchiefe
Vnto my vertuous Friend, hath ſhifted ſhapes
With that unblemiſhed beauty.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Do not rave Sir,
Nor let the violence of thoughts diſtract ye,
You ſhall enjoy me: I am yours: I pitty
By thoſe faire eyes I do.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O double hearted,
O woman, perfect woman: what diſtraction
Was meant to mankind when thou was't made a devill,
What an invyting hell invented? tell me,
And if you yet remember what i • goodneſſe,
Tell me by that, and truth, can one ſo cheriſh'd
So ſainted in the ſoule of him, whoſe ſervice
Is almoſt turn'd to ſupperſtition,
Whoſe every day endeavours, and deſires
Offer themſelves like incenſe on your altar,
Whoſe heart holds no int • lligence, but holy
And moſt religious with his love; whoſe life
(And let it ever be remembred Lady)
Is drawne out only for your ends.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O miracle.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Whoſe all, and every part of man: pray make me
Whoſe breath is but your bubble. Can ye, dare ye,
Muſt ye caſt of this man, though he were willing,
Though in a noblenes, ſo croſſe my danger
His friendſhip durſt confirme it, without baſeneſſe,
Without the ſtaine of honour? ſhall not people
Say liberally hereafter, ther's the Lady
That loſt her Father, Friend, herſelfe, her faith too,
To fawne upon a ſtranger, for ought you know
As faithleſſe as your ſelfe, in love as fruitleſſe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Take her withall my heart, thou art ſo honeſt
That tis moſt neceſſary I be undone.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: With all my ſoule poſſeſſe her. Exit, Val.
Till this minut.
I ſcorn'd, and hated ye, and came to coſen ye:
Vtter'd thoſe things might draw a wonder on me,
To make ye mad.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Good heaven, what is this woman?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Nor did your danger, but in charity.
Move me a whit: nor you appeare unto me
More then a common object, yet, now truely,
Truely, and nobly I doe love ye deerely,
And from this houre, ye are the man I honour,
You are the man, the excellence, the honeſty,
The onely friend, and I am glad your ſickneſſe
Fell ſo moſt happily at this time on ye,
To make this truth the worlds.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Whether doe you drive me?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Backe to your honeſty, make that good ever,
'Tis like a ſtrong built Caſtle, ſeated high,
That drawes on all ambitions, ſtill repaire it,
Still fortifie it: there are thouſand foes
Beſides the tyrant beauty, will aſſaile it:
Looke to your Centin is that watch it hourely,
Your eyes, let them not wander.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Is this ſerious?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Or do's ſhe play ſtill with me?
Keep your eares,
The two maine ports that may betray ye ſtrongly
From light beliefe firſt, then from flattery,
Eſpecially where woman beats the parley:
The body of your ſtrength, your noble heart
From ever yeelding ro diſhoneſt ends,
Rigd round about with vertue, that no breaches,
No ſubtle mynes may meet ye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How like the Sun
Labouring in his eclipſe, darke, and prodigious,
She ſhew'd till now? when having won her way,
How full of wonder he breakes out againe,
And ſheds his vertuous beames: excellent Angell,
For no leſſe can that heavenly minde proclaime thee,
Honour of all thy ſexe, let it be lawfull,
And like a pilgrim thus I kneele to beg it,
Not with prophane lips now, nor burnt affections,
But, reconcil'd to faith, with holy wiſhes,
To kiſſe that virgin hand.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Take your deſire ſir,
And in a nobler way, for I dare truſt ye,
No other fruit my love muſt ever yeeld yee,
I feare no more: yet your moſt conſtant memory
(So much I am wedded to that worthineſſe)
Shall ever be my friend, companion, husband,
Farewell, and fairely governe your affections,
Stand, and deceive me not: O noble yong man,
I love thee with my ſoule, but dare not ſay it:
Once more farewell, and proſper. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Goodneſſe guide thee:
My wonder like to fearefull ſhapes in dreames,
Has wakened me out of my fit of folly,
But not to ſhake it off: a ſpell dwels in me,
A hidden charme ſhot from this beauteous woman,
That fate can ne'r avoid, nor phyſicke finde,
And by her counſell ſtrengthen'd: onely this
Is all the helpe I have, I love faire vertue.
Well, ſomething I muſt doe, to be a friend,
Yet I am poore, and tardy: ſomething for her too,
Though I can never reach her excellence,
Yet but to give an offer at a greatneſſe.

div.stage: Enter Valentine, Thomas, Hylas, and Sam.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Be not uncivill Tom, and take your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Doe you think I am mad? you'l give me leave
To try her fairely?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Doe your beſt.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Why there boy,
But wher's the ſicke man?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Where are the gentlewomen
That ſhould attend him, ther's the patent
Me thinks theſe women.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Thou thinkſt nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Goe to him friend, and comfort him: Ile leade ye:
O my beſt joy, my worthieſt friend, ptay pardon me,
I am ſo over-joy'd I want expreſſion:
I may live to be thankfull: bid your friends welcome.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: How do'ſt thou Frank? how do'ſt thou boy, beare up man:
What, ſhrink i'th ſinewes for a little ſickneſſe?

l.hi: Deavolo morte.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I am o'th mending hand.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: How like a Flute thou ſpeak'ſt: o'th mending hand man
Gogs bores, I am well, ſpeake like a man of worſhip.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Thou art a mad companion: never ſtaid Tom?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Let rogues be ſtaid that have no habitation,
A gentleman may wander: ſit thee down Frank,
And ſee what I have brought thee: come diſcover,
Open the ſceane, and let the work appeare,
A friend at need you rogue is worth a million.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What haſt thou there, a julip?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: He muſt not touch it,
'Tis preſent death.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Ye are an Aſſe, a twirepipe,
A Ieffrey John bo peepe, thou mimiſter,
Thou mend a left-handed pack-ſaddle, out puppey,
My friend Frank, but a very fooliſh fellow:
Do'ſt thou ſee that bottle? view it well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I doe Tom.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: There be as many lives in't, as a Cat carries,
'Tis everlaſting liquor.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Old Sack boy,
Old reverend Sack, which for ought that I can reade yet,
Was that Philoſophers Stone the wiſe King Ptolomeus
Did all his wonders by.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I ſee no harme Tom,
Drinke with a moderation.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Drinke with ſuger;
Which I have ready here, and here a glaſſe boy,
Take me without my tooles.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Pray ſir be temperate,
You know your owne ſtate beſt.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, I much thanke ye,
And ſhall be carefull: yet a glaſſe or two
So fit I finde my body, and that ſo needfull.

sp.speaker: Tom,
sp.l: Fill it, and leave your fooling: thou ſay'ſt true Frank.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Where are theſe women I ſay?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Tis moſt neceſſary,
Hang up your julips, and your portugall poſſets,
Your barly brothes, and ſorrell ſops, they are mangy,
And breed the ſcratches onely: give me Sack:
I wonder where this wench is though: have at thee:

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: So long, and yet no bolting.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Doe, I'le pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Take it off thrice, and then cry heigh like a Huntſman
With a cleere heart, and no more fits I warrant thee.
The onely Cordiall Frank. Phiſ. within, & Serv.

sp.speaker: 1 Phiſ.
sp.l: Are the things ready?
And is the Barber come?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: An houre agoe ſir.

sp.speaker: 1 Phiſ.
sp.l: Bring out the oyles then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Now or never gentlemen,
Doe me a kindeneſſe and deliver me.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.l: From whom boy?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: From theſe things, that talke within there,
Phyſitians, Tom, Phyſitians, ſcowring-ſticks,
They meane to reade upon me.

div.stage: Enter three Phiſ. Apoth. and Barber.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Let 'em enter.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: And be thou confident, we will deliver thee:
For looke ye Doctor, ſay the divell were ſicke now,
His hornes ſaw'd off and his head bound with a Biggin,
Sicke of a calenture tak • n by a ſurfet
Of ſtinking ſoules at his nephews, and S. Dunſtans,
What would you miniſter upon the ſudden?
Your judgement ſhort and ſound.

sp.speaker: 1 Ph.
sp.l: A fooles head.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: No ſir,
It muſt be a Phyſitians for three cauſes,
The firſt becauſe it is a bald head likely,
Which will down eaſily without apple-pap.

sp.speaker: 3 Phiſ.
sp.l: A maine cauſe.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: So it is, and well conſider'd,
The ſecond, for 'tis fil'd with broken Greek ſir,
Which will ſo tumble in his ſtomacke, Doctor,
And worke upon the crudities, conceive me
The feares, and the fidle ſtrings within it,
That thoſe damn'd ſoules muſt diſembogue againe.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Or meeting with the ſtygian humour.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Right ſir.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Forc'd with a cataplaſme of crackers.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Ever.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Scowre all before him, like a Scavenger.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Satis feciſti domine: my laſt cauſe,
My laſt is, and not leaſt, moſt learned Doctors,
Becauſe in moſt Phyſitians heads (I meane thoſe
That are moſt excellent, and old withall,
And angry, though a patient ſay his prayers,
And Paracelſians that doe trade with poyſons,
We have it by tradition of great writers)
There is a kinde of toad-ſtone bread, whoſe vertue
The Doctor being dri'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Phiſ.
sp.l: We are abus'd ſirs.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I take it ſo, or ſhall be, for ſay the belly-ake
Caus'd by an inundation of Peaſe-porridge,
Are we therefore to open the port veyne,
Or the port Eſquiline?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: A learned queſtion:
Or grant the diaphragm • by a rupture,
The ſigne being then in the head of Capricorne.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Meet with the paſſion Hupercondriaca,
And ſo cauſe a carnoſitie in the kidneyes.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Muſt not the brains being butter'd with this humour
Anſwer me that.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.l: Moſt excellently argued.

sp.speaker: 2 Phiſ.
sp.l: The next fit you will have, my moſt fine ſchol
Bedlam ſhall finde a ſalve for: fare ye well ſir,
We came to do • you good, burtheſe yong Doctors
It ſ • emes have boar'd our noſes.
Drinke hard Gentlemen,
And get unwholeſome drabs: 'tis ten to one then
We ſhall heare further from ye; your note alter'd. Ex.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: And wilt thou be gone ſaies one?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: And wilt thou be gone ſaies to'ther?

sp.speaker: Toas.
sp.l: Then take the odde crowne
To mend thy old gowne.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: And we'l be gone all together.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My learned Tom.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, the yong Gentlewomen
Sent me to ſee what company ye had with ye
They much deſire to viſite ye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pray ye thanke 'em,
And tell 'em my moſt ſickneſſe is their abſence:
Ye ſee my company.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Come hither Crab,
What gentlewomen are theſe? my Miſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: And who elſe?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Miſtreſſe Alice.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Harke ye ſirha.
No word of my being here, unleſſe ſhe know it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I doe not thinke ſhe do's.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Take that, and mum, then

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: You have ty'd my tongue up. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Sit you downe good Francis,
And not a word of me till ye heare from me,
And as you finde my humour, follow it:
You two come hither, and ſtand cloſe, unſeen boyes,
And doe as I ſhall tutor ye.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What, new worke?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Prethee no more, but helpe me now,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I would faine
Talke with the gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Talke with the gentlewomen?
Of what forſooth? whoſe maiden-head the laſt maske
Suffer'd impreſſion, or whoſe clyſter wrought beſt:
Take me as I ſhall tell thee.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: To what end?
What other end came we along?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Be rul'd though.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Your wee zell face muſt needs be ferretting
About the farthing-ale,
Doe as I bid ye,
Or by this light.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Come then,

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Stand cloſe and marke me,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: All this forc'd foolery will never doe it.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: I hope we bring ye health ſir: how is't with ye?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: You look far better truſt me, the freſh colour
Creeps now againe into his cheeks.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Your enemy
I ſee has done his worſt. Come, we muſt have ye
Luſty againe, and frolicke man; leave thinking

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Indeed it do's ye harme ſir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My beſt viſitants,
I ſhall be govern'd by ye.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: You ſhall be well then,
And ſuddenly, and ſoundly well.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: This ayre ſir
laying now ſeaſon'd ye: will keep ye ever.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No, no, I have no hope, nor is it fit friends,
My life has bin ſo lewd, my looſe condition,
Which I repent too late, ſo lamentable,
That any thing but curſes light upon me,
Exorbitant in all my waies.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Who's that ſir,
Another ſicke man.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sure, I know that voyce well.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: In all my courſes, cureleſſe diſobedience.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What a ſtrange fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No counſell friends,
No looke before I leapt.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Doe yo' know the voyce ſir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis a gentlemans that's much afflicted
In's minde: great pitty Ladies.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Now heaven help him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: He came to me, to aske free pardon of me,
For ſome things done long ſince, which his diſtemper
Made to appeare like wrong, but 'twas not ſo.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O that this could be truth.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Perſwade your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: To what end gentlemen, when all is periſh'd
Vpon a wrack, is there a hope remaining?
The ſea, that nev'r knew ſorrow, may be pittifull,
My credit's ſpilt, and ſunke, nor is it poſſible,
Were my life lengthened out as long as.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I like this well.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Your minde is too miſtruſtfull.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I have a vertuous ſiſter, but I ſcorn'd her,
A Miſtreſſe too, a noble gentlewoman,
For goodneſſe all out-going.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Now I know him.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: With theſe eyes friends, my eyes muſt nev'r ſee more.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: This is for your ſake Mary: take heed coſen,
A man is not ſo ſoone made.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: O my fortune,
But it is juſt, I be deſpis'd and hated.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Deſpaire not, 'tis not manly: one houres goodneſſe
Strikes off an infinite of ils.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Weepe truly
And with compaſſion Coſin.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How exactly
This cunning yong theefe plaies his part.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Well Tom
My Tom againe, if this be truth.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: She weepes boy.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: O I ſhall die.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now heaven defend.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Thou haſt her.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Come lead me to my Friend to take his farewell,
And then what fortune ſhall befall me, welcome.
How do's it ſhow?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: O rarely well.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Say you ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O ye grand Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And are ye there my Iuggler
Away we are abus'd Alice.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Foole be with thee. Exit. Ma. and Al.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Where is ſhe.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Gon; ſhe found you out, and finely,
In your own nooze ſhe halter'd ye: you muſt be whiſpering
To know how things ſhowd: not content to fare well
But you muſt roare out roſt meate; till that ſuſpition
You carried it moſt neately, ſhe beleeved too
And wept moſt tenderly; had you continew'd,
Without doubt you had brought her off.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: This was thy Rouging.
For thou wert ever whiſpering: fye upon thee
Now could I breeks thy head.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: You ſpoke to me firſt.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Do not anger me,
For by this hand ile beate the buzard blind then
She ſhall not ſcape me thus: farewell for this time,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Good night, tis almoſt bed time: yet no ſleepe
Muſt enter theſe eyes, till I worke a wonder. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt along too, for I meane to plague thee
For this nights ſins, I will nev'r leave walking of thee
Till I have worne thee out.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Your will be done Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: You will not leave me Sam.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Away then: ile be your guid now, if my man be truſty
My ſpightfull Dame, ile pipe ye ſuch a huntſup
Shall make ye daunce a tipvaes: keepe cloſe to me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: NEver perſwade me, I will marry againe
What ſhould I leave my ſtate to, pins & poaking ſticks
To Farthingals, and frownces, to fore-horſes
And a old leather bawdy houſe behind'en
To thee?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You have a ſonne Sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Where, what is he?
Who is he like?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou lyeſt, thou haſt mard him,
Thou, and thy praier bookes: I do diſclaime him:
Did not I take him ſinging yeſternight
A godly Ballad, to a godly tune too,
And had a catechizme in's pocket Damſell,
One of your deare diſciples, I perceive it?
When did he ride abroad ſince he came over?
What Taverne h • s he us'd to? what hings done
That ſhewes a man, and mettle? when was my houſe
At ſuch a ſhame before, to creep to bed
At ten a clocke, and twelve, for want of company?
No ſinging, nor no dauncing, nor no drinking?
Thou think'ſt not of theſe ſcandals; when, and where
Has he but ſhewd his ſword of late.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Diſpaire not
I do beſeech you Sir, nor tempt your weakneſſe,
For if you like it ſo, I can aſſure you
He is the ſame man ſtill.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Would thou wert aſhes
On that condition; but beleeve it goſſip
You ſhall know you have wrong.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You never Sir,
So will I know my duty: and for heaven ſake,
Take but this councell with ye ere you marry,
You were wont to beare me: take him, and confeſſe him
Search him toth' quicke, and if you find him faile
Do as pleaſe you; a Mothers name I honour.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He is loſt, and ſpoil'd I am reſolv'd my rooffe
Shall never harbour him: and for your Minion
Ile keepe you cloſe enough, leaſt you breake looſe
And do more michiefe; get ye in: who waits. Exit. Dor.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Do you call Sir?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Seeke the Boy: and bid him wait
My pleaſure in the morning: marke what houſe
He is in, and what he do's: and truly tell me.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I will not faile Sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: If ye do, ile hang ye. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: KEepe you the backe doore there, and be ſure
None of her ſervants enter, or goe out,
If any woman paſſe, ſhe is lawfull prize, boyes
Cut off all convoyes.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Who ſhall anſwere this?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Why, I ſhall anſwere it, you fearefull widgen,
I ſhall appeare toth' action.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: May we diſcourſe too
On honourable tearmes?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: With any gentlewoman
That ſhall appeare at window: ye may rehearſe too
By your commiſſion ſafely, ſome ſweet parcels
Of poetry to a Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: May we ſing too?
For ther's my maſter-piece.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: By no meanes, no boyes,
I am the man reſerv'd for ayre, 'tis my part,
And if ſhe be not rock, my voyce ſhall reach her:
Ye may record a little, or ye may whiſtle,
As time ſhall miniſter, but for maine ſinging,
Pray ye ſatisfie your ſelves: away, be carefull.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: But hark ye one word Tom, we may be beaten.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: That's as ye think good your ſelves: if you deſerve it,
Why 'tis the eaſieſt thing to compaſſe: beaten?
What bugbeares dwell in thy brains? who ſhould beat thee?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: She has men enough,

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Art not thou man enough too?
Thou haſt fleſh enough about thee: if all that maſſe
Will not maintaine a little ſpirit, hang it,
And dry it too for dogs meat: get you gone;
I have things of moment in my minde: that doore,
Keep it as thou would'ſt keep thy wife from a Servingman.
No more I ſay: away Sam.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: At your will ſir. Exit Hyl. & Sam.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I have him here, a rare rogue, good ſweet maſter,
Doe ſomething of ſome ſavour ſuddenly,
That we may eat, and live: I am almoſt ſtarv'd,

l.hi: No point manieur, no point devein, no Signieur,

sp.l: Not by the vertue of my languages,
Nothing at my old maſters to be hoped for,
O Signieur du, nothing to line my life with,
But cold Pyes with a cudgell, till you help us.

sp.speaker: Tho.
