sp.l: Nothing but famine frights thee: come hither Fidler,
Whad Ballads are you ſeen in beſt: be ſhort ſir.

sp.speaker: Fidler
sp.l: Vnder your maſterſhips correction, I can ſing
The Duke of Norfolke, or the merry Ballad
Of Diverus and Lazarus, the Roſe of England,
In Creet when Dedimus firſt began,
Jonas his crying out againſt Coventry,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Excellent,
Rare matters all.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Mawdlin the Merchants daughter,
The Divell, and ye dainty Dames.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Rare ſtill.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: The landing of the Spaniards at Bow,
With the bloudy battell at Mile-end.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: All excellent:
No tuning as ye love me; let thy Fidle
Speake welch, or any thing that's out of all tune,
The vilder ſtill the better, like thy ſelfe,
For I preſume thy voyce will make no trees dance.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Nay truely, ye ſhall have it ev'n as homely.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Keep ye to that key, are they all abed trow?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I heare no ſtirring any where, no light
In any window, 'tis a night for the nonce Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Come ſtrike up then: and ſay the Merchants daughter,
We'l beare the burthen: proceed to inciſion Fidler. Song.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Who's there? what noyſe is this? what rogue
At theſe houres?

sp.speaker: Thom.

l.hi: O what is that to you my foole?
O what is that to you,
Plucke in your face you bawling Aſſe,
Or I will breake your brow.

sp.l: A new Ballad, a new, a new.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: The twelfth of Aprill, on May day,
My houſe and goods were burnt away, &c. Maid above.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Why who is this?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: O damſell deere,
Open the doore, and it ſhall appeare,
Open the doore,
O gentle ſquire.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: I'le ſee thee hang firſt: farewell my deere,
'Tis maſter Thomas, there he ſtands.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange
That nothing can redeeme him: raile him hence,
Or ſing him out in's owne way, any thing
To be deliver'd of him.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Then have at him:
My man Thomas did me promiſe.

l.hi: He would viſite me this night.
I am here Love, tell me deere Love,
How I may obtaine thy ſight.
Come up to my window love, come, come, come,
Come to my window my deere,
The winde, nor the raine, ſhall trouble thee againe,
But thou ſhalt be lodged here.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: And art thou ſtrong enough?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Vp, up, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: What do'ſt thou meane to doe?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Good Miſtreſſe peace,
I'le warrant ye wee'l coole him: Madge, Madge above.

sp.speaker: Madge
sp.l: I am ready.

sp.speaker: Tho.

l.hi: The loue of Greece and it tickled him ſo,
That he deviſed a way to goe.

sp.l: Now ſing the Duke of Northumberland.

l.hi: And climbing to promotion,
He fell down ſuddenly,
l.stage: Madge with a divels vizard roring, offers to kiſſe him, and he fals down.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Farewell ſir.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: What haſt thou done? thou haſt broke his neck.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Not hurt him,
He pitcht upon his legs like a Cat,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O woman:
O miſerable woman, I am ſpoil'd,
My leg, my leg, my leg, oh both my legs.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I told thee what thou hadſt done, miſchiefe go with thee,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O I am lam'd for ever: O my leg,
Broken in twenty places: O take heed,
Take heed of women, Fidler: oh a Surgeon,
A Surgeon, or I dye: oh my good people,
No charitable people, all deſpightfull,
Oh what a miſery am I in: oh my leg.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Be patient ſir, be patient: let me binde it.

div.stage: Enter Samuel and Hylas with his head broken.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Oh doe not touch it rogue.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: My head, my head,
Oh my head's kil'd.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: You muſt be courting wenches
Through key-holes, Captain Hylas, come and be comforted,
The skin is ſcarce broke.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O my leg.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: How doe ye ſir?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Oh maim'd for ever with a fall, he's ſpoil'd too,
I ſee his braines.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Away with me for Gods ſake,
A Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Here's a night indeed.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: A Surgeon. Exit all but Fidler.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Goe run for helpe.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Oh,

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Run all, and all too little,
O curſed beaſt that hurt him, run, run, flye,
He will be dead elſe.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Good friend goe you too.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Who payes me for my Muſicke?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Pox o'your Muſicke,
Ther's twelve pence for ye.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ther's two groates againe forſooth,
I never take above, and reſt ye merry. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A greaſe pot guild your fidle ſtrings: how do you,
How is my deere?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Why well I thank ye ſweet heart,
Shall we walke in, for now ther's none to trouble us?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Are ye ſo crafty ſir? I ſhall meet with ye,
I knew your tricke, and I was willing: my Tom,
Mine owne Tom, now to ſatisfie thee, welcome, welcome,
Welcome my beſt friend to me, all my deereſt.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Now ye are my noble Miſtreſſe: we looſe time ſweet.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I thinke they are all gone.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: All, ye did wiſely.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And you as craftily.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: We are well met Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Come, let's goe in then lovingly: O my Skarfe Tom.
I loſt it thereabout, finde it, and weare it
As your poore Miſtreſſe favour. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I am made now,
I ſee no venture is in no hand: I have it,
How now? the doore lock't, and ſhe in before?
Am I ſo trim'd?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: One parting word ſweet Thomas,
Though to ſave your credit, I diſcharg'd your Fidler,
I muſt not ſatisfie your folly too ſir,
Ye'are ſubtle, but beleeve it Foxe, i'le finde ye,
The Surgeons will be here ſtrait, rore againe boy,
And breake thy legs for ſhame, thou wilt be ſport elſe,
Good night.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: She ſaies moſt true, I muſt not ſtay: ſhe has bobd me,
Which if I live, I'le recompence, and ſhortly,
Now for a Ballad to bring me off againe.

l.hi: All yong men be warn'd by me, how you do goe a wooing.
Seek not to climb, for feare ye fall thereby, comes your undoing, &

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: HE cannot goe and take no farewell of me,
Can he be ſo vnkinde? he's but retir'd
Into the Garden or the Orchard: ſee ſirs.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: He would not ride there certain, thoſe were planted
Onely for walkes I take it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ride, nay then,
Had he horſe out?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: So the Groome delivers
Somewhat before the breake of day.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He's gone,
My beſtfriends gone Alice? I have loſt the nobleſt,,
The trueſt, and the moſt man I ere found yet.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Inded ſir, he deſerves all praiſe.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: All ſiſter,
All, all, and all too little: O that honeſty,
That ermine honeſty, unſpotted ever,
That perfect goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Sure he will returne ſir,
He cannot be ſo harſh.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: O never, never,
Never returne, thou know'ſt not where the cauſe lyes.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: He was the worthieſt welcome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He deſerv'd it.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Nor wanted, to our knowledge.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: I will tell thee,
Within this houre, things that ſhall ſtartle thee.
He never muſt returne. Enter Michael.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Good morrow Signieur.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good morrow maſter Michael.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: My good neighbour,
Me thinks you are ſtirring early ſince your travell,
You have learn'd the rule of health ſir, where's your miſtres?
She keeps her warme I warrant ye, a bed yet?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: I thinke ſhe do's.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: T'is not her houre of waking.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Did you lye with her Lady?

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Not to night ſir.
Nor any night this weeke elſe.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: When laſt ſaw ye her?

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Late yeſter night.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Was ſhe abed then?

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: No ſir,
I left her at her prayers: why doe ye aske me?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I have been ſtrangely haunted with a dreame
All this long night, and after many wakings,
The ſame dreame ſtill; me thought I met yong Cellide
Iuſt at S. Katherines gate the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Her face ſlubber'd o're with teares, and troubles,
Me thought ſhe cry'd unto the Lady Abbeſſe,
For charity receive me holy woman,
A Maid that has forgot the worlds affections,
Into thy virgin order: me thought ſhe tooke her,
Put on a Stole, and ſacred robe upon her,
And there I left her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Dreame?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Good Miſtreſſe Alice
Doe me the favour (yet to ſatisfie me)
To ſtep but up, and ſee.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: I know ſhe's there ſir,
And all this but a dreame?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: You know not my dreames,
They are unhappy ones, and often truths,
But this I hope, yet

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: I will ſatisfie ye, Exit.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Neighbours, how do's the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know not,
Dreame of a Nunnery?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: How found ye my words
About the nature of his ſickneſſe Valentine?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Did ſhe not cry out, 'twas my folly too
That forc'd her to this Nunnery? did ſhe not curſe me?
For God ſake ſpeake: did you not dreame of me too,
How baſely, poorely, tamely, like a foole,
Tir'd wi • h his joyes?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Alas poore gentleman.
Ye promis'd me ſir to beare all theſe croſſes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I beare 'em till I breake againe.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: But nobly,
Truely to weigh,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good neighbours, no more of it,
Ye doe but fling flaxe on my fire: where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Not yonder ſir, nor has not this night certaine
Bin in her bed.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: It muſt be truth ſhe tels ye,
And now I'le ſhew ye why I came: this morning
A man of mine being employed about buſineſſe,
Came early home, who at S. Katherines Nunnery,
About day peep told me he met your Miſtreſſe,
And as I ſpoke it in a dreame, ſo troubled
And ſo received by the • bbeſſe, did he ſee her?
The wonder made me riſe, and haſte unto ye
To know the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Farewell, I cannot ſpeake it. Exit Ʋal.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: For heaven take leave him not.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I will not Lady.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Alas, he's much afflicted,

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: We ſhall know ſhortly more, apply your own care
At home good Alice, a • d truſt him to my counſell.
Nay, doe not weep, all ſhall be well, deſpaire not. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: AT Valentines houſe ſo merry?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: As a pie Sir:

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: So gameſon doſt thou ſay?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I am ſure I heard it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ballads, and Fidles too?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: No, but one Fidle;
But twenty noyces. Enter Launcelet.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Did he do deviſes?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The beſt deviſes ſir: her's my fellow Launcelet
He can informe ye all: he was among 'em,
A mad thing too: I ſtood but in a corner.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Come ſir, what can you ſay? is there any hope yet
You Maſter may returne?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: He went far elſe
I will aſſure your worſhip on my credit
By the faith of a Travellor, and a Gentleman,
Your ſonne in found againe, the ſonne, the Tom.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Is he the old Tom?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The old Tom.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Goe forward.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Next, to conſider how he is the old Tom.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Handle me that.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I would ye had ſeene it handled
Laſt night ſir, as we handled it: cap à pe,
Footte for leers, and learings; O the noyſe
The noyſe we made.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Good, good.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The windowes clattring
And all the Chambermaides, in ſuch a whobub,
One with her ſmocke halfe off; another in haſt
Wi • h a ſerving mans hoſe upon her head.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Good ſtill.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: A fellow rayling out of a loop hole there
And his mouth ſtopt with durt.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: y'faith a fine Boy.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Here one of our heads broke.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Excellent good ſtill.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The gentleman himſelfe yong M. Thomas,
Invirond with his furious Mermidons
The fiery Fidler, and my ſelfe; now ſinging,
Now beating at the doore, there parlying,
Courting at that window, at the other ſcalling
And all theſe ſeverall noyſes to two Trenchers,
Strung with a bottome of browne thred, which ſhowd admirable.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: There eate, and grow againe, I am pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Nor here ſir.
Gave we the frolicke over: though at length
We quit the Ladies Skonce on compoſition
But to the ſilent ſtreetes we turn'd our furies:
A fleeping watchman here we ſtole the ſhooes from,
There made a noyſe, at which he wakes, and followes:
The ſtreetes are durty, takes a queene hith cold,
Hard cheeſe, and that choakes him o' Munday next:
Windowes, and ſignes we ſent to Erebus;
A crue of bawling curs we entertain'd laſt,
When having let the pigs looſe in out pariſhes,
O the brave cry we made as high as Algate!
Downe comes a Conſtable, and the Sow his Siſter
Moſt trayterouſly tramples upon Authority,
There a whole ſtand of rug gownes rowted manly
And the Kings peace put flight: a purblind pig here
Runs me his head into the Admirable Lanthorne,
Out goes the light, and all turnes to confuſion:
A Potter riſes, to enquire this paſſion
A Boare imboſt takes ſanctuary in his ſhop.
When twenty dogs ruſh after, we ſtill cheering
Down goes the pots, and pipkins, down the pudding pans,
The creame bols cry revenge here, there the candleſticks.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: If this be true, thou little tyny page
This tale that thou tell'ſt me
Then on thy backe will I preſently hang
A handſon new Levery:
But if this be falſe, thou little tyney page
As falſe it well may be
Then with a cudgell of foure foote long
Ile beate thee from head to toe. Enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Will the boy come.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He will ſir. Enter Thomas.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Time tries all ther.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Here he comes now himſelfe ſir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: To be ſhort Thomas
Becauſe I feele a ſcruple in my conſcience
Concerning the demeanour, and a maine one
And therefore like a Father would be ſatisfi'd,
Get up to that window there, and preſently
Like a moſt compleat Gentleman, come from Tripoly.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.l: Good Lord ſir, how are you miſled: what fancies
(Fitter for idle boyes, and drunkards, let me ſpeak't
And with a little wonder I beſeech you)
Choake up your noble judgement?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You Rogue Launcelet,
You lying raſcall.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Will ye ſpoile all agen ſir.
Why, what a devill do you meane?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Away knave,
Ye keepe a company of ſawcy fellowes
Deboſh'd, & dai • y drunkards, to deavoure ye,
Things, whoſe dull ſoules, tend to the Celler only,
Ye are ill advis'd ſir, to commit your credit.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sirha, ſirha.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Let me never eate againe ſir,
Nor feele the bleſſing of another blew-coate
If this yong Gentleman, ſweet Maſter Thomas
Be not as mad as heart can wiſh: your heart ſir,
If yeſternights diſcourſe: ſpeake fellow Robin
And if thou ſpeakeſt leſſe then truth.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Tis ſtrange theſe varlets.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: By theſe ten bones ſir, if theſe eies, and eares
Can heare and ſee.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Extreame ſtrange, ſhould thus boldly
Bud in your ſight, unto your ſonne.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: O deu guin
Can ye deny, ye beat a Conſtable
Laſt night.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I touch Authoritie ye raſcall?
I violate the Law?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Good M. Thomas.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Did you not take two Wenches from the Watch too
And put 'em into pudding lane?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: We meane not
Thoſe civill things you did at M. Valentines
The Fidle, and the fa'las,

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: O ſtrange impudence?
I do beſeech you ſir give no ſuch licence
To knaves and drunkards, to abuſe your ſonne thus:
Be wiſe in time, and turne'em off: we live ſir
In a State govern'd civilly, and ſoberly
Where each mans actions ſhould confirme the Law,
Not cracke, and canzell it.

sp.speaker: Seb.

l.hi: Lancelot du Lake

sp.l: Get you upon adventers: caſt your coate
And make your exit.

sp.speaker: Lan.

l.hi: Pur la mour de dieu

sp.l: Pur me no purs: but pur at that doore, out ſirha
Ile beate ye purblind elſe, out ye eight languages,

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: My bloud upon your head. Exit. Lan.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Purge me'em all ſir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And you too preſently.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Even as you pleaſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Bid my maid ſervant come: and bring my daughter
I will have one ſhall pleaſe me. Exit ſer.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Tis moſt fit ſir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Bring me the money there: here M. Thomas,
sp.stage: Enter two ſervants with two bags.
sp.l: I pray ſit downe, ye are no more my ſonne now,
Good gentleman be cover'd

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: At your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This money I do give ye, becauſe of whilom
You have bin thought my ſonne, and by myſelfe too,
And ſome things done like me: ye are now another
There is two hundred pound, a civill ſome
For a yong civill man: much land and Lordſhip
Will as I take it now, but prove temptation
To dread ye from your ſetled, and ſweet carriage.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: You ſay right ſir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Nay I beſeech ye cover.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: At your diſpoſe: and I beſeech ye too ſir,
Fot the word civill, and more ſetled courſe
It may be put to uſe, that on the intereſt
Like a poore Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It ſhall, to my uſe
To mine againe: do you ſee ſir: good fine gentleman,
I give no brooding money for a Scrivener,
Mine is for preſent trafficke, and ſo ile uſe it.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: So much for that then.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: For the maine cauſe Mounſieur
I ſent to treat with you about, behold it;
Behold that peice of ſtory worke, and view it
I want a right heire to inherir me,
Not my eſtate alone, but my conditions,
From which you are revolted, therefore dead,
And I will breake my backe, but I will get one.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Will you chooſe there ſir?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: There, among thoſe Damſels,
In mine owne tribe: I know their quallities
Which cannot faile to pleaſe me: for their beauties
A matter of a three farthings, makes all perfect,
A little beere, and beeffe broth: they are ſound too.
Stand all a breaſt: now gentle M. Thomas
Before I chooſe, you having liv'd long with me,
And happely ſometimes with ſome of theſe too,
Which fault I never frown'd upon: pray ſhew me
(For feare we confound our Genealogies)
Which have you laid aboord? ſpeake your mind freely
Have you had copulation with that Damſell?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Stand you a ſide then: how with her ſir?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: How, is not ſeemely here to ſay.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Heer's fine ſport.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Retyre you too: ſpeake forward M. Thomas.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I will: and to the purpoſe; even with all ſir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: With all that's ſomewhat large.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And yet you like it
Was ever ſinne ſo glorious?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: With all Thomas.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: All ſurely ſir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A ſigne thou art mine owne yet,
In againe all: and to your ſeverall functions. Exit. Maides.
What ſay you to yong Luce, my neighbours daughter,
She was too yong I take it, when you travelled;
Some twelve yeare old?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Her will was fifteene ſir,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A pretty anſwere, to cut of long diſcourſe,
For I have many yet to aske ye of,
Where I can chooſe, and nobly, hold up your finger
When ye are right: what ſay ye to Valeria;
Whoſe husband lies a dying now? why two,
And in that forme?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Her husband is recover'd.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A witty morall: have at ye once more Thomas,
The ſiſters of St. Albones, all five; dat boy,
Dat's mine owne boy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Now our upon thee Monſter.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Still hoping of your pardon.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: There needes none man:
A ſtraw on pardon: prethee need no pardon:
Ile aske no more, nor thinke no more of marriage,
For O my conſcience I ſhalbe thy Cuckold:
Ther's ſome good yet left in him: beare your ſelfe well,
You may recover me, ther's twenty pound ſir,
I ſee ſome ſparkles which may flame againe,
You may eat with me when you pleaſe, you know me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why do you lye ſo damnably, ſo fooliſhly?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Do'ſt thou long to have thy head broke? hold thy peace
And doe as I would have thee, or by this hand
I'le kill thy Parrat, hang up thy ſmall hand,
And drinke away thy dowry to a penny.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Was ever ſuch a wilde Aſſe?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Prethee be quiet,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And do'ſt thou think men will not beat thee monſtrouſly
For abuſing their wives and children?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: And do'ſt thou thinke
Mens wives and children can be abus'd too much?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I wonder at thee.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Nay, thou ſhalt adjure me
Before I have done.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How ſtand ye with your miſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I ſhall ſtand neerer
Ere I be twelve houres older: ther's my buſineſſe,
She is monſtrous ſubtile Doll.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.l: The divell I thinke
Cannot out ſubtle thee.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: If he play faire play,
Come, you muſt helpe me preſently.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I diſcard ye.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not ſleep nor eate.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I'le no hand with ye,
No bawd to your abuſes.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: By this light Doll,
Nothing but in the way of honeſty.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Thou never knew'ſt that road: I heare your vigile

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Sweet honey Doll, if I doe not marry her,
Honeſtly marry her, if I meane not honourably,
Come, thou ſhalt help me, take heed how you vex me,
I'le help thee to a husband too, a fine gentleman,
I know thou art mad, a tall yong man, a brown man,
I ſweare he has his maidenhead, a rich man.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You may come in to dinner, and I'le anſwere ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nay I'le goe with thee Doll: four hundred a yeere wench. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: GOod ſir go back again, and take my counſell,
Sores are not cur'd by ſorrows, nor time broke from us,
Pul'd back again by ſighes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What ſhould I doe friend?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Doe that that may redeeme ye, goe back quickly,
Sebaſtians daughter can prevaile much with her,
The Abbeſſe is her Aunt too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But my friend then
Whoſe love and loſſe is equall ty'd.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Content ye,
That ſhall be my taske if he be alive,
Or where my travell and my care may reach him,
I'le bring him backe againe.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Say he come backe
To piece his poor friends life out? and my miſtreſſe
Be vow'd for ever a recluſe?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: So ſuddenly
She cannot, haſte ye therefore inſtantly away ſir,
To put that daughter by firſt as to a father,
Then as a friend ſhe was committed to ye,
And all the care ſhe now has: by which priviledge
She cannot doe her this violence,
But you may breake it, and the law allowes ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O but I forc'd her to it.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Leave diſputing
Againſt your ſelfe, if you will needs be miſerable
Spight of her goodneſſe, and your friends perſwaſions,
Thinke on, and thrive thereafter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will home then,
And follow your adviſe, and good, good Michael.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: No more, I know your ſoul's divided Valentine,
Cure but that part at home with ſpeedy marriage
Ere my returne, for then thoſe thoughts that vext her,
While there ran any ſtreame for looſe affections,
Will be ſtopt up, and chaſte ey'd honour guide her
Away, and hope the beſt ſtill: I'le worke for ye,
And pray too heartily, away, no more words Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I Care not for my broken head,
But that it ſhould be his plot, and a wench too,
A lowzie, lazie wench prepar'd to doe it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Thou hadſt as good be quiet, for o' my conſcience
He'l put another on thee elſe.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I am reſolv'd
To call him to account, was it not manifeſt
He meant a miſchiefe to me, and laughed at me,
When he lay roaring out, his leg was broken,
And no ſuch matter: had he broke his necke,
Indeed 'twould ne'r ha griev'd me: gallowes gall him,
Why ſhould he chooſe out me?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Thou art ever ready
To thruſt thy ſelfe into theſe ſhe occaſions,
And he as full of knavery to accept it.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Well, if I live, I'le have a new tricke for him.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: That will not be amiſſe, but to fight with him
Is to no purpoſe: beſides, he's truely valiant,
And a moſt deadly hand: thou never foughtſt yet,
Not o' my conſcience haſt no faith in fighting.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: No, no, I will not fight.

sp.speaker: Sam,
sp.l: B • ſide the quarrell,
Which has a woman in't, to make it ſcurvy,
Who would lye ſtinking in a Surgeons hands
A moneth or two this weather; for beleeve it,
He never hurts under a quarters healing.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: No upon better thought, I will not fight Sam,
But watch my time

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: To pay him with a project:
Watch him too, I would wiſh ye: prethee tell me,
Do'ſt thou affect theſe women ſtill?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Yes faith Sam,
I love 'em ev'n as well as ev'r I did,
Nay, if my braines were beaten out, I muſt to 'em.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Doſt thou love any woman?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Any woman
Of what degree or calling.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Of any age too?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Of any age, from fourſcore to fourteen boy,
Of any faſhion.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: And defect too?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Right.
For thoſe I love to leade me to repentance:
A woman with no noſe, after my ſurquedry,
Shewes like King Philips morall, memento mori,
And ſhe that has a wodden leg, demonſtrates
Like Hypocrites, we halt before the gallowes:
An old one with one tooth, ſeemes to ſay to us
Sweet meats have ſowre ſawce: ſhe that's full of aches,
Crum not your bread before you taſte your porridge,
And many morals we may finde.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis well ſir,
Ye make ſo worthy uſes: but quid igitur,
What ſhall we now determine?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Let's conſider,
An houre or two, how I may fit this fellow.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Let's finde him firſt, he'l quickly give occaſion,
But take heed to your ſelfe, and ſay I warn'd ye:
He has a plaguy pate.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: That at my danger. Exeunt. Muſick.

div.head: Scena Quinta.
div.stage: Enter Saylors ſinging to them, Michael and Francis.

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l: ABoard, aboard, the winde ſtands faire.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Theſe call for paſſengers, I'le ſtay, & ſee
What men they take aboard.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A boat, a boat, a boat.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Away then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Whether are ye bound friends?

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l: Downe to the Straytes.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Ha, 'tis not much unlike him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: May I have paſſage for my money?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: And welcome too.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: 'Tis he, I know 'tis he now.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Then merrily aboard, and noble friend
Heauens goodneſſe keep thee ever, and all vertue
Dwell in thy boſome Cellide, my laſt teares
J leave behinde me thus, a ſacrifice,
For I dare ſtay no longer to betray ye.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Be not ſo quicke ſit: Saylors I here charge ye
By vertue of this warrant, as you will anſwer it,
For both your ſhip and Merchant I know perfectly:
Lay hold upon this fellow.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Fellow?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: J ſir.

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l: No hand to ſword ſir, we ſhall maſter ye,
Fetch out the manacles.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I doe obey ye:
But I beſeech ye ſir, informe me truely
How I am guilty.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Ye have rob'd a gentleman,
One that ye are bound to for your life and being:
Money and horſe unjuſtly ye tooke from him,
And ſomething of more note, but for y'are a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſo, and here I'le end all miſeries,
Since friendſhip is ſo cruell, I confeſſe it,
And which is more, a hundred of theſe robberies:
This Ring I ſtole too from him: and this jewell
The firſt and laſt of all my wealth: forgive me
My innocence and truth, for ſaying I ſtole 'em,
And may they prove of value but to recompence
The thouſand part of his love, and bread I have eaten.
Pray ſee 'em render'd noble ſir, and ſo
I yeeld me to your power.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Guard him to'th water,
I charge you Saylors, there I will receive him,
And backe convey him to a Iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Come ſir,
Look to your neck, you are like to ſayle i'th ayre now.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: COme quickly, quickly, quickly, paint me handſomly
Take heed my noſe be not in graine too,
Come Doll, Doll, diſen me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If you ſhould play now
Your divels parts againe.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Yea and nay Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: If ye doe any thing, but that ye have ſworne to,
Which onely is acceſſe.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: As I am a gentleman:
Out with this hayre Doll, handſomely.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: You have your breeches?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I prethee away, thou know'ſt I am monſtrous tickliſh,
What do'ſt thou think I love to blaſt my buttocks?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: I'le plague ye for this roguery: for I know well
What ye intend ſir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: On with my Muffler.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Ye are a ſweet Lady: come let's ſee you curtſie:
What broke i'th bum, hold up your head.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Plague on't
I ſhall he piſſe my breeches if I cowre thus,
Come, am I ready.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: At all points, as like ſir
As if you were my Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Who goes with ye.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: None but my fortune, and my ſelfe. Exit. Tho.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Bleſſe ye
Now run thou for thy life, and get before him,
Take the by way, and tell my Coſin Marie
In what ſhape he intends to come to coz n her
Ile follow at thy heeles my ſelfe: flie wench

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Ile do it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: My Father has met him: this goes excellent
And ile away in time: looke to your skin Thomas. Exit. Gillian.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What, are you growne ſo corne ſed gooddy
You will not know your Father: what vaga'res
Have you in hand, what out leapes, durty heeles
That at theſ • houres of night ye muſt be gadding,
And through the Orchard take your private paſſage;
What, is the breeze in your breech, or has your brother
Appointed you an houre of meditation
How to demeane himſelfe: get ye to bed, drab
Or ile ſo crab your ſhoulders: ye demure ſlut
Ye civill diſh of ſliced beefe get ye in.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I wy' not, that I wy' not.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Is't ev'n ſo Dame
Have at ye with a night ſpell then.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Pray hold ſir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: St. Geoge, St. George, our Ladies knight
He walkes by day, ſo do's he by night,
And when he had her found
He her beat, and her bound,
Vntill to him her troth ſhe plight,
She would not ſtir from him that night.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nay then have at ye with a counter-ſpell,
From Elves, Hobs and Fayries, that trouble our Dayries,
From Fire-drakes and fiends, and ſuch as the divell ſends,
Defend us heaven. Exi

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Bleſſe my Maſter: looke up ſir I beſeech ye,
Vp with your eyes to heaven.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Vp with your noſe ſir,
I doe not bleed, 'twas a ſound knock ſhe gave me,
A plaguy mankinde gi • le, how my braines totters?
Well, go thy waies, thou haſt got one thouſand pound more
With this dog tricke,
Mine owne true ſpirit in her too,

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: In her, alas ſir,
Alas poore gentlewoman, ſhe a hand ſo heavy
To knocke ye like a Calfe down, or ſo brave a courage
To beat her father? if you could beleeve ſir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Who wouldſt thou make me beleeve it was, the divell?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: One that ſpits fire as faſt as he ſometimes ſir,
And changes ſhapes as often: your ſonne Thomas:
Never wonder, if it be not he, ſtraight hang me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He? if it be ſo,
I'le put thee in my Will, and ther's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: J ſaw his legs, has Boots on like a Player,
Vnder his wenches cloaths: 'tis he, 'tis Thomas
In his own ſiſters cloaths, ſir, and I can waſt him.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No more words then, we'l watch him: thou'lt not beleeve Lance,
How heartily glad I am.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: May ye be gladder,
But not this way ſir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No more words, but watch him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: VVHen comes he?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Preſently.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then get you up Doll,
Away, I'le ſtrait come to you: is all ready?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: All.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Let the light ſtand far enough.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: 'Tis placed ſo.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Stay you to entertaine him to his chamber,
But keep cloſe wench, he flyes at all.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You need no more inſtruction?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: I am perfect. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: MOre ſtops yet? ſure the fiend's my ghoſtly father,
Old Ʋalentine: what wind's in his poope?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Lady,
You are met moſt happily: O gentle Doll,
You muſt now doe me an eſpeciall favour.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: What is it Maſter Valentine? I am ſorely troubled
With a ſalt rheume falne i'my gums.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le tell ye,
And let it move you equally: my bleſt Miſtreſſe
Vpon a ſlight occaſion taking anger,
Tooke alſo (to undoe me) your Aunts Nunnery,
From whence by my perſwaſion to redeeme her,
Will be impoſſible: nor have I liberty
To come, and viſite her: my good, good Dorothy,
You are moſt powerfull with her, and your Aunt too,
And have acceſſe at all houres liberally,
Speake now, or never for me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: In a Nunnery?
That courſe muſt not be ſuffered Maſter Ʋalentine,
Her mother never knew it: rare ſport for me:
Sport upon ſport, by th' breake of day I'le meet ye,
And feare not man, wee'l have her out I warrant ye,
I cannot ſtay now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You will not breake?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: By no meanes.
Good night.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good night kinde Miſtreſſe Doll. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: This thrives well,
Every one takes me for my ſiſter, excellent:
This Nunnerys fal ſo pat too, to my figure,
Where there be handſome wenches, and they ſhall know it
If once I creep in, ere they get me out againe:
Stay, her's the houſe and one of her Maids.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Who's there?
O Miſtreſſe Dorothy you are a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Still Miſtreſſe Dorothy? this geere will cotton.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Will you walke in forſooth?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Where is your Miſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Not very well: ſhe's gone to bed, I am glad
You are come ſo fit to comfort her.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Yes, I'le comfort her.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Pray make not much noiſe, for ſhe is ſure aſleep,
You know your ſide, creep ſoftly in, your company
Will warme her well.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I warrant thee I'le warme her.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Your brother has been here, the ſtrangeſt fellow.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: A very rogue, a ranke rogue.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: I'le conduct ye
Even to her chamber door, and there commit ye. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: COme ſir, for this night I ſhall entertaine ye,
And like a gentleman, how ere your fortune
Hath caſt ye on the worſt part.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How you pleaſe ſir,
I am reſolv'd, nor can a joy or miſery
Much move me now.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I am angry with my ſelfe now
For putting this forc'd way upon his patience,
Yet any other courſe had been too ſlender:
Yet what to thinke I know not, for moſt liberally
He hath confeſs'd ſtrange wronge, which if they prove ſo,
How ere the others long love may forget all,
Yet 'twas moſt fit he ſhould come back, and this way
Drinke that: and now to my care leave your priſoner,
I'le be his guard for this night.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Good night to your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Good night my honeſt friends: Come ſir, I hope
There ſhall be no ſuch cauſe of ſuch a ſadneſſe
As you put on.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Faith ſir, my reſt is up,
And what I now pull, ſhall no more afflict me
Then if I plaid at ſpan-counter, nor is my face
The map of any thing I ſeeme to ſuffer,
Lighter affections ſeldome dwell in me ſir.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: A conſtant gentleman: would I had taken
A feaver when I took this harſh way to diſturb him,
Come walke with me ſir, ere to morrow night
I doubt not but to ſee all this blown over. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I Have dog'd his ſiſter, ſure 'twas ſhe,
And I hope ſhe will come back again this night too:

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.l: I have loſt of purpoſe: now if I can
With all the art I have, as ſhe comes backe,
But win a parley for my broken pate,
Off goes her maiden-head, and there's vindicta.
They ſtir about the houſe, I'le ſtand at diſtance. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Mary and Dorothy, and then Thomas & Maid.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Is he come in?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Speake ſoftly,
He is, and there he goes.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Good night, good night wench.

div.stage: a bed diſcovered with a black More in it.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: As ſoftly as you can. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I'le play the Mouſe Nan,
How cloſe the little thiefe lyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How he itches?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: What would you give now to be there, and I
At home Mall?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Peace for ſhame.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: In what a figure
The little foole has pull'd it ſelfe together:
Anone you will lye ſtreighter:
Ha, ther's rare circumſtance
Belongs to ſuch a treatiſe: doe ye tumble,
I'le tumble with ye ſtraight wench: ſhe ſleeps ſoundly,
Full little thinkſt thou of thy joy that's comming,
The ſweet, ſweet joy, full little of the kiſſes,
But thoſe unthought of things come ever happieſt.
How ſoft the rogue feeles? Oye little villaine,
Ye delicate coy thiefe, how I ſhall thrum ye?
Your fy away, good ſervant, as ye are a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Prethee leave laughing.
Out upon ye Thomas
What do ye meane to do? ile call the houſe up,
O god, I am ſure ye will not, ſhall not ſerve ye,
For up ye goe now, and ye were my Father.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your courage wilbe cold anon.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: If it do hang for'
Yet ile be quarterd here firſt.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O feirce villaine.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What would he do indeed Doll?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You had beſt try him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Ile kiſſe thee ere I come to bed: ſweet Mary.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Prethee leave laughing.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O, for gentle Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And view that ſtormy face, that has ſo thundered me,
A coldne's crept over't now; by your leave, candle,
And next doore by yours too, ſo, a pretty, pretty
Shall I now looke upon ye: by this light it moves me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Much good may it do you ſir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Holy ſaints, defend me.
The devill, devill, devill, devill, O the devill.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Dor. Ha, ha, ha, ha, the devill O the devill.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I am abus'd moſt damnedly: moſt beaſtly,
Yet if it be a ſhe devill: But the houſe is up,
And here's no ſtaying longer in this Caſſock,
Woman, I here diſclaime thee; and in vengeance
Ile marry with that devill, but ile vex thee.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Byr' Lady, but you ſhall not ſir, ile watch ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Plague O your ſpaniſh leather hide; ile waken ye:
Devill, good night: good night good devill.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Rore againe, devill, rore againe. Ex. Tho.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: O, O, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Open the doores before him: let him vaniſh.
Now, let him come againe, ile uſe him kinder
How now Wench.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Pray lye here your ſelf, next Miſtris
And entertaine your ſweet heart.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What ſaid he to thee.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I had a ſoft bed: and I ſlept out all,
But his kind farewell: ye may bake me now
For O my conſcience, he has made me veniſon.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Alas poore Kate; ile give thee a new Petticoate,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And I a Waſtcoate, Wench.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Draw in the bed Maides,
And ſee it made againe; put freſh ſheetes on too,
For Doll. and I: come Wench, lets laugh an houre now,
To morrow earely, will wee ſee yong Cellide
They ſay ſhe has taken Sanctuary: love, & they
Are thicke ſowne, but come up ſo full of thiſtles.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: They muſt needs Mall: for 'tis a pricking age grown
Prethee to bed, for I am monſtrous ſleepy.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A match, but art not thou thy brother?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Would I were Wench,
You ſhould heare further.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Come, no more of that Doll. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I Heard the doores clap: now, and't be thy will, wench
By th' mas ſhe comes: you are ſurely melt faire gentlewoman,
I take it Miſtris Doll, Sebaſtians daughter.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I take right ſir: Hylas, are you feretting
Ile fit you with a pennyworth preſently.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: How dare you walk ſo late ſo ſweet: ſo weak guarded?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Faith ſir, I do no harme, nor none I looke for
Yet I am glad, I have met ſo good a gentleman,
Againſt all chances: for though I never knew ye
Yet I have heard much good ſpoke of ye,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Harke ye.
What if a man ſhould kiſſe ye?

sp.speaker: Tho,
sp.l: That's no harme ſir,
Pray God he ſcapes my heard, there lyes the miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Her lips are monſtrous rugged, but that ſurely
Is but the ſharpneſſe of the weather: harke ye once more,
And in your eare, ſweet Miſtreſſe, for ye are ſo,
And ever ſhall be from this houre: I have vow'd it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why that's my daughter, rogue, do'ſt thou not ſee her
Kiſſing that fellow there, there in that corner?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Kiſſing?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Now, now, now they agree o'th match too.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nay then ye love me not.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: By this white hand Doll.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe, I have long deſir'd your ſight ſir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Why ther's the Boots ſtill ſir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Hang Boots ſir,
Why they'l weare breeches too.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Diſhoneſt me
Not for the world.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why now they kiſſe againe, there
I knew 'twas ſhe, and that her crafty ſtealing
Out the back way muſt needs have ſuch a meaning.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I am at my ſmall wits end.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: If ye meane honourably.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Did ſhe nev'r beat ye before ſir?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why do'ſt thou follow me?
Thou raſcall ſlave haſt thou not twice abus'd me?
Haſt thou not ſpoil'd the boy? by thine owne covenant,
Would'ſt thou not now be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I thinke I would ſir,
But you are ſo impatient: do's not this ſhew ſir,
(I do beſeech ye ſpeake, and ſpeake with judgement,
And let the caſe be equally conſidered)
Far braver in your daughter? in a ſon now
'Tis nothing, of no marke: every man do's it,
But, to beget a daughter, a man maiden
That reaches at theſe high exploits, is admirable:
Nay ſhe goes far beyond him: for when durſt he,
But when he was drunke, doe any thing to ſpeake of?
This is Sebaſtian truely.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou ſayeſt right Lance,
And ther's my hand once more.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Not without marriage.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Didſt thou heare that?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I thinke ſhe ſpoke of marriage,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And he ſhall marry her, for it ſeems ſhe likes him,
And their firſt boy ſhall be my heire.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I marry
Now ye goe right to worke.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Fye, fye ſir,
Now I have promis'd ye this night to marry,
Would ye be ſo intemperate? are ye a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I have no maw to marriage, yet this raſcall
Tempts me extreamely: will ye marry preſently?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Get you afore, and ſtay me at the Chappell,
Cloſe by the Nunnery, there you ſhall finde a night Prie ••
Little ſir Hugh, and he can ſay the Matrimony
Over without booke, for we muſt have no company
Nor light, for feare my father know, which muſt not yet
And then to morrow night.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Nothing to night ſweet?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No, not a bit, I am ſent of buſineſſe
About my dowry, ſweet, doe not you ſpoile all now,
'Tis of muh haſte. I can ſcarce ſtay the marriage,
Now if you love me, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: You'l follow?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Within this houre, my ſweet chicke.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: A rope kiſſe ye,
Come, come, I ſtand o'thornee.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Me thinkes her mouth ſtill
Is monſtrous rough, but they have waies to mend it,
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Farewell, I'le fit ye with a wife, ſir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Come, follow cloſe, I'le ſee the end ſhe aymes at,
And if he be a handſome fellow Launcelot,
• iat, 'tis done, and all my ſtate is ſetled. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: COme, to your Mattins Maids: theſe early houres
My gentle daughter, will diſturb a while,
Your faire eyes, nurterd in eaſe.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No vertuous mother,
Tis for my holy health, to purchaſe which
They ſhall forget the childe of eaſe, ſoft ſlumbers,
O my afflicted heart, how thou art tortur'd,
And Love, how like a tyrant, thou raign'ſt in me,
Commanding and forbidding at one inſtant:
Why came I hither that deſire to have
Onely all liberty, to make me happy?
Why didſt thou bring that yong man home, O Ʋalentine,
That vertuous youth, why didſt thou ſpeake his goodneſſe
In ſuch a phraſe, as if all tongues, all praiſes
Were made for him? O fond and ignorant,
Why didſt thou foſter my affection
Till it grew up, to know no other father,
And then betray it?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Can ye ſing?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yes, Mother,
My ſorrowes onely.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Be gone, and to the Quire then. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena ſeptima.
div.stage: Enter Michael and Servant, and Francis.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: HA'ſt thou inquir'd him out?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He's not at home ſir,
His ſiſter thinks he's gone to th' Nunnery,

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Moſt likely: I'le away, an houre hence ſirha,
Come you along with this yong gentleman,
Doe him all ſervice, and faire office.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes ſir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: VVHere haſt thou been man?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Is there nev'r a ſhop open?
I'le give thee a paire of gloves Sam.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: What do'ſt thou thinke?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Thou art not married?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: By th' maſſe but I am, all to be married,
I am i'th order now Sam.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: To whom prethee?
I thought there was ſome ſuch trick in't, you ſtole from me
But who, for heaven ſake?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Ev'n the ſweeteſt woman,
The rareſt woman Samuel, and the luſtieſt,
But wondrous honeſt, honeſt as the ice boy,
Not a bit before hand, for my life, ſirha,
And of a luſty kindred.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: But who Hylas?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: The yong gentleman and I are like to be friends againe,
The fates will have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Who, Monſieur Thomas?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: All wrongs forgot.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O now I ſmell ye Hylas.
Do's he know of it?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: No, ther's the tricke I owe hi •
Tis done boy, we are faſt faith, my youth now
Shall know I am aforehand, for his qualities.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Is there no tricke in't?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: None, but up and ride boy:
I have made her no joynture neither, there I have paid him.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: She's a brave wench.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: She ſhall be, as I'le uſe her,
And if ſhe anger me, all his abuſes
I'le clap upon her Caſſocke.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Take heed Hylas,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: 'Tis paſt that Sam, come, J muſt meet her preſently,
And now ſhalt ſee me, a moſt glorious husband.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: IN troth ſir, you never ſpoke to me.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Can ye forget me?
Did not you promiſe all your helpe and cunning
In my behalfe, but for one houre to ſee her,
Did you not ſweare it? by this hand, no ſtrictneſſe
Nor rule this houſe holds, ſhall by me, be broken.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I ſaw ye not theſe two dayes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Doe not wrong me,
I met ye, by my life, juſt as you entred
This gentle Ladies Lodge laſt night, thus ſuited
About eleven a clocke.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Tis true I was there,
But that I ſaw or ſpoke to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have found it,
Your brothor Thomas, Doll.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pray ſir be ſatisfi'd,
And wherein I can doe you good, command me,
What a mad foole is this? ſtay here a while ſir,
Whilſt we walke in, and make your peace. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I thanke ye. ſqueake within.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter there among theſe Maids?
Now benedicite, have ye got the breeze there?
Give me my holly ſprinckle.

sp.speaker: 1 Nun
sp.l: O Madam, ther's a ſtrange thing like a gentlewoman,
Like Miſtreſſe Dorothy, I think the fiend
Crept in to th' Nunnery we know not which way,
Playes revell rowt among us.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Give me my holy water pot.

sp.speaker: 1 Nun
sp.l: Here Madam.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Spirit of earth or ayre, I do conjure thee, ſqueake within
Of water or of fire.

sp.speaker: 1 Nun
sp.l: Harke Madam, hark.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Be thou ghoſt that cannot reſt: or a ſhadow of the bleſt,
Be thou black, or white, or green, be thou heard, or to be ſeen

sp.speaker: 2 Nun
sp.l: It comes, it comes.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: What are ye? ſpeake, ſpeake gently,
And next, what would ye with me?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Any thing you'l let me.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: You are no woman certaine.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Nor you no Nun, nor ſhall not be.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What make ye here?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I am a holy Fryer.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Is this the Spirit?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nothing but ſpirit Aunt.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Now out upon thee.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Peace, or I'le conjure too Aunt.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Why come you thus?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: That's all one, her's my purpoſe:
Out with this Nun, ſhe is too handſome for ye,
I'le tell thee (Aunt) and I ſpeake it with teares to thee,
If thou keptſt her here, as yet I hope thou art wiſer,
Mark but the miſchiefe followes.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: She is a Votreſſe.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Let her be what ſhe will, ſhe will undoe thee,
Let her but one houre out, as I direct ye,
Or have among your Nuns againe.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: You have no project
But faire and honeſt?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: As thine eyes, ſweet Abbeſſe,

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: I will be ruld then.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Thus then and perſwade her
But do not iuggle with me, if ye do Aunt.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: I muſt be there my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Away and fit her.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Come daughter, you muſt now be rull'd, or never.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: I muſt obey your will.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: That's my good daughter. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: VVHat a coyle has this Fellow kept i'th' Nunnery
Sure he has run the Abbeſſe out of her wits.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Out of the Nunnery I think, for we can neither ſee her
Nor the yong Cellide.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray heavens he be not teaſing.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay you may thanke your ſelfe, 'twas your owne ſtructures.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Why there's the gentlewoman,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Mas tis ſhe indeed
How ſmart the pretty theefe lookes? 'morrow Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Good morrow to you ſir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: How ſtrange ſhe beares it?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Maids muſt do ſo, at firſt.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Would ye ought with us, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Yes marry would I
A little with your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Your will ſir.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Doll, I would have ye preſently prepare your ſelfe
And thoſe things you would have with you,
For my houſe is ready.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How ſir?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: And this night not to faile, you muſt come to me,
My Friends will all be there too: For Trunks, & thoſe things
And houſhold ſtuffe, and clothes you would have carried
To morrow, or the next day, ile take order:
Onely, What money you have, bring away with ye,
And Iewels:

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Iewels ſir?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I, for adornement
There's a bed up, to play the game in, Dorothy,
And now come kiſſe me heartily.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: This Lady ſhalbe welcome too.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: To what ſir?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Your neighbour can reſolve ye.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The man's fooliſh
Sir, you looke ſoberly: who is this fellow,
And where's his buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: By heaven, thou art abus'd ſtill.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: It may be ſo: Come, ye may ſpeake now boldly
There's none but friends, Wench.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Came ye out of Bedlam?
Alas, tis ill ſir, that ye ſuffer him
To walke in th' open ayre thus: 'twill undoe hlm.
A pretty hanſome gentleman: great pitty.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Let me not live more if thou be'ſt not cozens,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Are not you my Wife? did not I marry you laſt night
At St. Michaels Chappell?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Did not I ſay he was mad?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Are not you Miſtreſſe Dorothy, Thomas ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There he ſpeakes ſence, but ile aſſure ye gentleman,
I think no Wife of yours: at what houre was it?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: S' pretious; you'll make me mad; did not the Prieſt
Sir Hugh that you appointed, about twelve a clocke
Tye our hands faſt? did not you ſweare you lov'd me?
Did not I court ye, comming from this gentlewomans?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Good ſir, goe ſleepe: for if I credit have
She was in my armes, then, abed.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I told ye.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Be not ſo confident.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: By th' mas, ſhe muſt ſir.
For ile no husband here, before I know him:
And ſo good morrow to ye: Come, let's goe ſeeke'em.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I told ye what ye had done.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Is the devill ſtirring?
Well, goe with me: for now I wilbe married. Exeunt

div.head: Scena Vndecima.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I Have brought him backe againe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You have don a friendſhip
Worthy the love you beare me.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Would he had ſo too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O he's a worthy yong man.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: When al's tryde
I feare you'l change your faith: bring in the gentleman.

div.stage: Enter Francis, and ſervant, and Abbeſſe, and Cellide, ſeverally.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My happy Miſtreſſe too: now Fortune helpe me,
And all you ſtarres, that governe chaſt deſires
Shinne faire, and lovely.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: But one houre, deere Daughter,
To heare your Guardian, what he can deliver
In Loves defence, and his: and then your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Though much unwilling, you have made me yeeld,
More for his ſake I ſee: how full of ſorrow
Sweet catching ſorrow, he appeares? O love,
That thou but knew'ſt to heale, as well as hurt us.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Be ruld by me: I ſee her eye faſt on him:
And what ye heard, beleeve, for tis ſo certaine
He neither dar'd, nor muſt oppoſe my evidence;
And be you wiſe, yong Lady, and beleeve too.
This man you love, Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As I love my ſoule, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: This man you put into a free poſſeſſion
Of what his wants could aske: or your ſelfe render?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And ſhall do ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mich
sp.l: Nothing was bard his libertie
But this faire Maide; that friendſhip firſt was broken,
And you, and ſhe abus'd; next, (to my ſorrow
So faire a forme ſhould hide ſo darke intentions,)
He hath himſelfe confes'd (my purpoſe being
Only to ſtop his Iourney, by that pollicy
Of laying fellony to his charge, to fright the Saylors)
Divers abuſes, done, thefts often practis'd,
Moneys, and Iewels too, and thoſe no trifles.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: O where have I beſtrew'd my faith: in neither:
Let's in for ever now, there is vertue.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Nay do not wonder at it, he ſhall ſay it,
Are ye not guiltie thus?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes: O my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: To give a proofe I ſpeake not enviouſly
Looke here: do you know theſe Iewels.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: In, good Mother.

div.stage: Enter Thomas, Dorothy, and Mary: then Sebaſtian and Launcelot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Theſe Iewels; I have knowne.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You have made brave ſport.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Ile make more, if I live Wench
Nay doe not looke on me: I care not for ye.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Do you ſee now plaine? that's Miſtris Dorothy,
And that's his Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Peace, let my joy worke eaſely
Ha, boy: art there my boy: mine owne boy, Tom. boy,
Home Lance, and ſtrike a freſh peece, of wine, the townes ours,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sure, I have knowne theſe Iewels.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: They are they, certaine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good heaven, that they were.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Ile pawne my life on't
And this is he; Come hither Miſtris Dorothy,
And Miſtris Mary: who do's that face looke like:
And view my brother well?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: In truth like him.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Vpon my troth exceeding like,

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Beſhrew me,
But much: and maine reſemblance, both of face
And lineaments of body: now heaven grant it.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: My brother's full of paſſion, I'le ſpeake to him.
Now, as you are a gentleman, reſolve me,
Where did you get theſe jewels?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Now I'le tell ye,
Becauſe blinde fortune yet may make me happy,
Of whom I had 'em, I have never heard yet,
But from my infancy, upon this arme
I ever wore'em.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: 'Tis Franciſco brother,
By heaven I ty'd 'em on: a little more ſir,
A little, little more, what parents have ye?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: None
That J know yet: the more my ſtubborne fortune,
But as J heard a Merchant ſay that bred me,
Who, to my more affliction, di'de a poore man,
When J reach'd eighteen yeers.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: What ſaid that Merchant?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: He ſaid, an infant, in the Genoway Galleyes.
But from what place he never could direct me.
I was taken in a ſea-fight, and from a Marriner,
Out of his manly pitty he redeem'd me.
He told me of a Nurſe that waited on me,
But ſhe, poore ſoule, he ſaid was killed.
A letter too, I had enclos'd within me,
To one Caſtructio a Venetian Merchant,
To bring me up: the man, when yeers allow'd me,
And want of friends compell'd, I ſought, but found him
Long dead before, and all my hopes gone with him.
The wars was my retreat then, and my travell
In which I found this gentlemans free bounty,
For which, heaven recompenc'd him: now ye have all.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And all the worldly bliſſe that heaven can ſend me,
And all my prayers and thanks.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Down o' your knees, ſir,
For now you have found a father, and that father
That will not venture ye againe in Gallyes.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: 'Tis true, beleeve her ſir, and we all joy with ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My beſt friend ſtill: my deereſt: now heaven bleſſe thee
And make me worthy of this benefit.
Now my beſt Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Now ſir, I come to ye.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: No, no, let's in wench.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not for the world, now, Mother,
And thus ſir, all my ſerviee I pay to you,
And all my love to him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And may it proſper,
Take her Franciſco: now no more yong Callidon,
And love her deerely, for thy father do's ſo.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: May all hate ſeek me elſe, and thus I ſeale it.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Nothing but mirth now, friends.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Nay, I will finde him.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: What doe all theſe here?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You are a truſty husband,
And a hot lover too.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Nay then, good morrow,
Now J perceive the knavery.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: J ſtill told ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Stay, or I'le make ye ſtay: come hither ſiſter,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why how now Miſtreſſe Thomas?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Peace a little,
Thou would'ſt faine have a wife?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Not I, by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l:
Thou ſhalt have a wife, & a fruitful wife, for I find •
Hylas known ſon agen.
That I ſhall never be able to bring thee children.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A notable brave boy.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I am very well ſir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt be better Hylas, thou haſt 7 hundred pound a yeer,
And thou ſhalt make her 3 hundred joynture.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt boy, and ſhalt beſtow
Two hundred pound in clothes, looke on her,
A delicate luſty wench, ſhe has fifteen hundred,
And ſeaſible: ſtrike hands, or I'le ſtrike firſt.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You'l let me like?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He's a good handſome fellow,
Play not the foole.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Strike, brother, Hylas quickly,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: If you can love me, well.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If you can pleaſe me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Try that out ſoon, I ſay, my brother Hylas.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Take her, and uſe her well, ſhe's a brave gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: You muſt allow me another Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then you muſt allow me another ſervant.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Well, let's together then, a luſty kindred.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I'le give thee five hundred pound more for that word.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now ſir, for you & I to make the feaſt full.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No, not a bit, you are a vertuous Lady,
And love to live in contemplation.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Come foole, I am friends now.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: The foole ſhall not ride ye,
There lye my woman, now my man againe,
And now for travell once more.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I'le bar that firſt.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And I next.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Hold your ſelfe contented: for I ſay I will travell,
And ſo long I will travell, till I finde a father
That I never knew, and a wife that I never look'd for,
And a ſtate without expectation,
So reſt you merry gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: You ſhall not
Vpon my faith, I love you now extremely,
And now J'le kiſſe ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: This will not doe it, Miſtreſſe,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why when we are married, we'l doe more,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ther's all boy,
The keyes of all I have, come, let's be merry,
For now I ſee thou art right.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Shall we to Church ſtraight?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now preſently, and there with nuptiall.
The holy Prieſt ſhall make ye happy all.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Away then, faire afore. Exeunt.
